It's not very good, but not because it has rape.
Goblin Slayer is a "dark" medevial fantasy dungeon crawler. It's a homage to Dungeons and Dragons. Characters go on quests and kill goblins.  I put "dark" in quotes because it really falls off being dark past the infamous first rape episode and becomes more lighthearted. And boring.
Characters: Generic and shallow. Goblin Killer is basically a walking joke. Kill Goblins, that's his personality. It's a pretty funny gag at first when characters react with "*exasperated sigh* all he cares about is killing Goblins.." but this quickly becomes old when it happens with every line of GoblinSlayer's dialogue and is nearly the sole source of comedy. These kind of blank slate characters can be fine, but not when it's the main character. 


The female protagonist is just as bland and uninteresting. She's generic anime female character with no personality other than mindless devotion to Goblin Slayer San. 


Lizard man: boring. Dwarf and Elf: Legolas and Gimli ripoff but Legolas is a generic tsundere and Gimli isn't funny. The latter 3 feel like cartoon characters and are part of the tonal issues with this show. 


World building: There isn't any. We are given generic fantasy land. I keep forgetting it's not an Isekai, that's how generic this world is. You have elves, warriors, basically DND adventurer types that live in villages and go on quests. 


An example of poor writing is how Goblins are considered "low level quests".  Goblins in this show are portrayed as extremely dangerous and sneaky, our introduction to them is them raping and killing a group of adventures. Adventurers go in on their first quest without any fear whatsoever. If Goblins really are so dangerous, word would spread about how much of a threat they are and they'd be made higher priority quests. The worst part of this is that the "guild girl" (quest giver) obviously knows they're all going to die and she doesn't even try to stop them besides a very weak "maybe you shouldn't, it's not easy..." Any sane person who has sent adventurers on quests and sees what happens would have firmly stopped them; the writing there is just laughable. This makes guild girl a detestable character but the show treats it like we're supposed to like her.


The whole notion of goblins being weak fodder enemies is a notion we the viewer gets from books, movies and video games that feature goblins as weaklings. In a world where they are not weakings and are a clear threat, this pre-concieved notion wouldn't arrise. 


To further the problem of Goblins being "low level" quests: We see Goblin Slayer going on multiple quests. Obviously if the story was just Goblin Slayer killing little goblins, the story would get boring fast. So it turns out he encounters Super Goblins, basically giant Goblins that are considered platinum rank. Platinum rank is one of the high tiers of adventurers; Super Goblins (or Ogres) being around on low level missions (multiple times) makes it laughable that Goblins are still conisdered low level quests in this world. This paired with the aforementioned horrible quest giving excuse; it's all extremely contrived and poorly thought out. 


Tone: The tone of this show is all over the place. Actually it starts out dark and shocking, with the rape scene. After that it turns into very generic comedy adventure isekai. They were trying to set the tone of this world with the first episode. The problem is that you can't just have one shocking thing happen, and then completely forget about it because what you just build up feels cheap and makes the show inconsistent. I have a hard time believing that rape happened in the first episode with how lighthearted things are in the later ones.


Story: There is no story. It's just Goblin Slayer enters dungeon with cute anime girl, elf, ilzard man and dwarf, kill goblins. Rince and repeat for the first 10 episodes. Needless to say it is hardly thrilling or compelling, defiinitely not one that makes you excited to see the next episode.  Watch the first 2 - 3 episodes. See how it goes from shock to shallow world building; and is already resorting to big tittie cowgirls to try to keep you interested. 


Action: The action and animation is dull. Nothing interesting happens. Goblin slayer often cleaves goblins in half with his sword... that's about it. There's no emotion behind the fight scenes because all of the enemies are just orcs and goblins with no personality behind "GRRR IM EVIL". If you compare a good show like Fullmetal Alchemist, every battle in that show wasn't just a battle, it was a dialogue between two opposing sides. That made it interesting. A battle doesn't need a dialogue back and forth but if there's no tension or good action to it - the goblins rarely put up a fight and we all know girl and Goblin Slayer aren't going to die - it's just a bore. 


Art: It's crap. It gets the job done, nothing special about it. Lots of cute girls. Talking heads. Very basic action. Not much to say about it. Character designs and scenes are all very dull looking and generic. Same goes for the sound.


Enjoyment: It's a bore because there's nothing to get invested in. The characters are flat and boring, the world building is laughably shoddy, and the story is non existent.


I imagine Goblin Slayer was written by someone who likes anime and wanted to make something edgy and cool but didn't really know what they were doing so they stuck in a bunch of anime tropes that they liked without understanding how those things worked.  What we got is a mess of different tropes thrown together haphazardly without any substance or depth.


Overall I give Goblin Slayer a 3/10. 


Thanks for the read. Let me know if there are typos. Goblin Slayer was a super disappointment to me as someone who loves edgy and dark shows. Have a great day.

As with all my reviews, this is SPOILER FREE. Don't listen to other idiots, there is no such thing as a "minor spoiler" in my eyes.
Goblin Slayer (GS from now on) has been the show that I've changed opinion on most this season. After watching episode 9 last night, I came to realize that it's my favorite this season. Here's why:
Story: 8/10. The story is interesting. There's a massive war going on with a Big Bad somewhere in the world, but we aren't a part of it. GS is like being a side quest. Occasionally you hear about progress being made in the war throughconversations, but GS isn't about that. I think it's an interesting approach to world-building not seen anywhere else I know of. The characters' motivations are clear. For Goblin Slayer, it's to kill goblins. For the others, it's to have adventures and kick ass. Simple, which is nice. Some small parts of the story become quite confusing and complex but in general it's a simple story.


Art: 7/10. This may be contentious. Let me explain. GS himself is always CGI if he's in armor. I think it was a good choice. He doesn't pop in and out of CGI which can be quite disruptive. The other characters are designed well, it's very easy to distinguish them from each other. They have some cool complexity to their designs. Expect lots of fan service though. Some people say the animation isn't great but frankly I haven't noticed any explicit parts where it's just bad. And it's good when it matters most.


Sound: 9/10. It's good. The OP is awesome, definitely my favorite in recent history. VAs seem good from what I can tell in the sub.


Characters: 10/10. The show makes an excellent choice here. It keeps the main cast to five characters who are always present. Rather than having different ones filter in and out, it can focus on these five. They each have distinct personalities that interact and clash with each other's. It's good for both comedy and drama. There are minor characters who recur, but the main 5 are the ones you'll be focusing on. 


Enjoyment: 10/10. Like I said, this show surprised me. I thought it would be all shock and awe with no depth, and would eventually get boring. While there was a bit of a mid-season drag that slowed the pacing, it was ultimately for the best by making the next arc that much more exciting. The world and the characters have a decent amount of depth for how simple their motivations are and the fact that they're basically a side-narrative, but these are both plusses in my eyes. 


Overall: 9/10. If the story picks up a bit, I think this show could be a masterpiece. As it stands, it's already outstanding and definitely deserves your attention for at least 6 episodes. I suggest giving it a shot.

For a series that starts off so dark, with gore, death and rape all in the first episode, Goblin Slayer feels like a big bunch of fluff. The characters are underdeveloped, the series is full of generic fantasy tropes, and none of this in a good way.
Where is the dark world of goblin slaying that was promised? If you were hooked from the first episode on a show that promised to be more than just another fantasy romp, then that's really a shame because you're probably not getting what you signed on for. At some point the shock of the initial episode fades away, andwe're left with...not a whole lot. We have in our party: a flat main character with a generic backstory albeit in very cool armor, the couple of girls that will stick by his side no matter what, and a trio that embodies all the classic adventuring anime stereotypes you could ever ask for. 


All this would be completely fine if Goblin Slayer stuck with its premise of an intense and brutal world killing goblins, but as the episodes drag on that's not at all what we get. The shock and surprise that the series starts out with never really come back in later episodes, and that's what makes this feel a bit cheap. Goblin Slayer promised to be different with a gruesome first episode, and then quickly backtracked, making sure that every bit of the show seems as generic as possible.


The one interesting point is that unlike many isekai or fantasy anime, Goblin Slayer seems to draw much more of its inspiration from western fantasy culture, with a lot of elements from games like Dungeons and Dragons being added in. It's cool, but just not enough to distinguish the show from anything else you could watch.


Goblin Slayer is disappointing, not because it has violence and rape, but because it uses these as the anime equivalent of clickbait. It draws you in promising to be different, a dark take on fantasy, but ends up giving you the exact opposite, pandering with every generic trope there is. For a show and premise that started off so unique and daring, its degraded down to none of that, and that's a real shame.

      Goblin Slayer is what the title states: It's about Goblin Slayer slaying goblins in all glorious rampaging fashion. Nothing more nothing less. Take the episode where the crew almost gets annihilated as GS lays there unconscious with massive blood loss and possible concussion. How did he survive? Even in another episode, the poison in GS almost seemingly to kill off GS but no, for some weird reason, they placed him in a situation where they need to heal GS through the ritual of virgin's resurrection by lying next to them nude. Wait, they could've done that with the sorceress in the first episode. why explain this now? If that were the case, they could've saved her while she was still alive?        I spoke of nothing but negatives because I couldn't think of something I can simply enjoy or find meaningful things of what the anime wants to convey other than "rape is bad". I guess it is nothing more than just mindless gore schlock that people like for some reason because it is comparable to Berserk and Dungeons and Dragons. But that's the thing, it has no identity because it's easy to compare the contents of Berserk to this pile of mess. The comparative evaluation between the two anime I mentioned previously are different in a whole different level. Berserk is dark fantasy and uses the genre with care of its world, characters, and even philosophy that plays heavily in the themes of Berserk. Goblin Slayer is just pure power fantasy. It uses its setting as a writing tool to fool the audience what they're expecting and writes whatever they want along the way. The rape scene in the first episode is a good example. Although the content is distressing and we all know rape is inherently bad by nature, it takes the subject material right off the bat and never mentioned again until it is necessary for the narrative. One of the examples I mentioned was the Sword Maiden's backstory; For a hero who slain the Demon Lord but was brutally raped by goblins since childhood, the way they presented her is overly sexual as the camera zoomed in her breast for gratuitous reasons almost like "fan service". It's really making the audience's intelligence feel insulted and lessens the credibility of the anime's "darker tone". The characters are one dimensional, the story has inconsistencies in moving the plot forward, the subject material isn't handled with care or nuanced, it is false expectations from what was established in the very beginning and uses it as an advantage to make the anime seem more than what meets the eye. Goblin Slayer is its own pedestal of bad but not as bad as Sword Art Online because its objectively bad.  




       It looks like I'm on a tangent here so I must close this off on a good note; I do not wish to encourage any quarrels against anyone who may like this kind of content, it's perfectly fine. This review is meant to analyze the massive flaws Goblin Slayer stand as its own anime, not an imitation or an inspiration of previous franchises. For those who are sensitive to this kind of subject material, are free to ignore the existence of Goblin Slayer. Don't be like the people on Twitter ranting with their moral superiority about what needs to be shown or not shown in entertainment media (and the AniTubers who wants to throw in politics in this, you probably know who I'm talking about). In the end, you are not a bad person for watching Goblin Slayer. If Goblin Slayer fits that criteria of your taste, it is up to you. If not, stay clear away from this. Just watch whatever you want to watch dude/gals. As for me, I feel quality in anime has decreased and Goblin Slayer is one of those examples. Goblin Slayer is mediocre in every way, shape, and form.  The only notable thing about it is its depiction of rape, which, surprise surprise, is the only thing anyone ever talks about.  I personally couldnt give a shits less about it, so that is the last time I will mention it in this review.
On the surface, I like the idea of this show a lot.  Taking a typically weak monster, and boosting it up to be the main antagonist of the show is a really neat concept.  It gives a lot of interesting realism to a fantasy story.  Sure, itsjust one child sized goblin with a rusty knife, but that wont make getting stabbed any less painful.  If done better, I think it could be really interesting.


However, in order to make this concession work, so much has to be waved away.  Why is Goblin Slayer the only dude who knows how dangerous they are?  Why does no one seem take issue with all of the stolen girls?  Why do other adventures, who seem to be scarred the same way our MC is, not seem to care anymore?  Where is the military in all this?  They mention it multiple times but the stories reason is "oh theyre just goblins".  No fucking way would anyone take that position in this universe, given how truly evil the goblins are.  This is my main complaint with the show.  The concept is good, but the execution raises more questions than it deserves.


All of this might be forgivable had anything else in the show been able to carry it.  Every one of the characters, save for the sword maiden and maybe the priestess, is boring and one note.  I dont know what it is about fantasy anime having boring protagonists, but Goblin Slayer sure is a snooze fest.  The "quirk" that he only repeats the same three things is funny once, but again, the concessions needed to have him be like that completely obliterates any intriguing dialogue for the whole show.  It can even be harmful like with the sword priestess where the audience didnt know what the fuck was going on since he cant have a normal conversation.  The side cast is just as one dimensional.  Elf is a tsundere, lizardman likes cheese, dwarf likes alcohol, cowgirl likes GS, guild girl likes GS, the adventurers like... adventuring.  Thats it.  


The visuals are whatever.  Half of the time, GS is 3D and it looks like garbage.  Some of the action is pretty sweet, but the rest sucks.  I wont comment on the rest, like sound, music, backgrounds, etc, since I just dont remember any of it.  Guess thats all I really need to say, huh?


To end, Ill list what I liked.  The DnD backdrop is cool, and it lends itself to the theme really well.  Like previously mentioned, some of the action is good.  The strategy that Goblin Slayer uses to slay goblins is usually fun.  The OP is alright.  Goblin Slayers red eye is rad as hell.  Guess thats about it.

Are you the kind of person who likes seeing overly positive teenagers who think they can do anything get a reality check?

The main character is pretty self explanatory. He hates goblins and doesn't care about anything else. Is the town being attacked by a dragon? Too bad. There are goblins to be slayed. Is your kingdom at war with a neighboring kingdom? Too bad. There are goblins to be slayed.
Every once in a while, some stupid teenagers get natural selection and goblin slayer avenges them in themost brutal way possible.\n\n
A lot of people complain about this show's apparent lack of story, but they simply cannot appreciate the complexity of it.\n\n
There is a whole chain of events going on in the world but goblin slayer keeps on killing goblins, no matter what happens to the world. While most anime put the main characters right in the heart of the main events, goblin slayer tells the story from a completely alienated point of view. Every once in a while the main characters feel the effects of world events, but they just keep killing goblins despite them.

I refuse to accept such a score! I refuse to agree with the masses! Goblin Slayer is underrated and here is WHY!
Right off the bat we start with a strong opening episode that tells us "this is no lighthearted adventure and all bad stuff happens". It's not a matter of being edgy, it's a matter of telling a story the right way! The dude has trauma, well justified trauma, nothing is wrong with the main character and side characters as far as I can see. The animation is mostly on point excluding some out of place looking CG armor, but it blends in well enough to not distract your from watching. Sound design is also nice, it doesn't feel artificial at all.

A classic type of RPG hack and slash like the good old days, except on hard mode. It gets gruesome so don't let the mellow cover picture trick you into thinking this is kid friendly. If I had to say something bad about this show it would be the generic story. Yet again we find ourselves against familiar foes with age old reasons to go on an adventure. You've probably heard this story a million times, but if you can forgive that one flaw there might be something special underneath. The lines are so far nothing special, with humor that falls flat and overly mellowpersonalities that make it difficult to make the case for "best character" in here. Characters range from lacking to solid, but nothing amazing has come up just yet. If I had to say something good about this show it would be the pacing. An unexpected introduction gives way for a quality paced adventure that takes it's time with each person they run into, it might remind you of how many similar shows these days get it totally wrong. Side characters often feel like a part of the main story and it's not rare to see familiar faces. This gives it the feel of a cast the show cares about. The daily depiction of ordinary, everyday routines adds depth and immersion, making you feel like you're with them along for the adventure. The soundtrack is very moody, swinging from mellow and gentle, to chaotically invigorating, giving action scenes a lot of flavor. Animation has it's up and it's downs: action animation has a nice touch, with a unique style it can call it's own. outside of battles the show can be a bit too stiff, like a plain old comic with little life. Unique camera angles add some emotion and perspective to situations that are dry. 

Overall it's a multi-class RPG like a retro game, but with a slow and steady approach that rewards loyal fans with great moments. Like a cardboard house, the flaws are very noticeable, but that doesn't mean it's not fun. I give it a 8.5/10

TL;DR Version: Slow and steady RPG adventure that's rough around the edges. Has it's flaws but also has considerable depth and will become addictively immersive.

Goblin Slayer is a great show. It has great characters, good designs, interesting themes, good plot and a damn great soundtrack. I haven't seen a good dark fantasy anime since re: zero, and it was like, 2 years ago. I really recommend you to watch it if you like RPG games or fantasy series, cause Goblin Slayer is an awesome interpretation of games like D&D.
For the sake of better understanding, I will refer to Goblin Slayer, the character, as GS, and for the anime, I will simply call it Goblin Slayer.
That review is REALLY long, so be prepared.
Story 9/10:
The story of Goblin Slayer is toldin a very good way. When the series need to explain something about the world, it is told to a character that shouldn't know about that or not told at all, only hinted. For example, at the very first scene, when the receptionist (best girl) explain how the ranks at the guild work, she explains it to a person (the priestess) that just entered the guild and doesn't know anything about what adventurers should be doing, or how they are classified. Another example, also in the first episode, is when you see that in the goblins' cave, there is a room where raped woman is (yes, there is rape in the series), and next to this room, there is a place where baby goblins are, so you can assume that goblins use woman to reproduce. This is supported by the fact that you see goblins through the entire episode, and there are no females.

Another thing about the story is that the pacing is well communicated, and everything that happens matches with what feeling you're supposed to feel, and everything that happens has a good reason to happen. I don't want to enter spoiler territory, so I'll just say that the overwhelming stuff that happens in the first episode makes complete sense. Everything seems really realistic.

Just a quick note, the scene where the party talk about the beliefs that they have is amazing in a worldbuilding standpoint.


Art 9/10:


The art of the show is pretty good. The character designs are well done and make sense if you think about what they actually are. GS, in special, is super well animated, and the gimmick with the glowing eye when he is about to kill monsters is super good looking. The show, in general, is well animated as well. The CG blends nicely with the environment most of the time. Mad House (the studio that made Overlord) should learn with White Fox (that made this anime) how to do it right.


Sound 10/10:


MAAAAAAAAAN, this soundtrack is lit. Every single BGM fits well with the scene and adds feeling to the situation. Example, in the 4th episode, when GS use the scroll (you will know what I am talking about if you watched the series), the music stops, making you think about what is happening, cause you are not certain if he actually used the scroll or turned into OP swordsman for some other reason at the moment. Actually, the soundtrack gets so much better when GS is in the scene every single time. The metal/rock music that plays every time that is goblin killing time does so much hype. The opening song fits perfectly to the series as well.


Characters 9/10:


GS: GS is a really well-written character. He is someone that is traumatized because of what happened to him, and because of that, he is all closed and doesn't know how to relax. He is always thinking about how to act if goblins appear and attack someone, and he doesn't matter if the world is ending, or if there is a treat to the humanity, he will just kill goblins. And GS is really good at it, actually, so he is silver rank, that is like, the second best rank. The concept of his character is interesting. The whole point of him is that somebody has to do the job that no one wants. I will return to that topic later.


Priestess: She is basically the "normal person"-character. This type of character is really important in that type of story where not everything needs to be explicitly said to you. It is really nice to see how much someone changes by being with GS and his crazy life and also shows contrast to him.


Elf: She is so fun. Really, she is someone that I would like to have as a friend. Her interactions with the dwarf are also really good. Her backstory about living 10000 years inside a forest, and became an adventurer to explore the world makes all sense if you see how she acts


Dwarf: He is a drunk dwarf. There is not much to him until that point in the series.


Lizardman: I love his respectful and calm personality even with the dark stuff that happens. His summoning magic is really cool too.


Goblins: The actual main characters. What makes goblins good villains is that everyone sees goblins as pure evil creatures. But if you think about all the cruel stuff that they do, like killing people and raping people, IT MAKES SENSE! They need to kill people that are threats to them, so they don't die and need to rape woman to reproduce, so it is completely justified to them to do that. Also, because they need to do that to survive, it is completely impossible to goblins and humans to coexist, making their fight with people really necessary. The fact that every single person underestimate them but they are pretty powerful in groups is a great concept. I should point out that you should hate goblins, cause despite they need to kill people, they are a threat to the society, and they probably would rape your mother and kill your friends if they could.


Party of the first episode (spoilers of the first episode here): They are a great picture of how it is dangerous to be alive in this world, and how nobody cares about what are the risks of being an actual adventurer here. The average anime mc of the group is all confident because he killed some goblins that tried to kill people in his village, but he doesn't think about the equipment that he using or the environment that he is fighting. The bitch wizard does not get close to the melee fighters and don't recognize the danger of dealing with close-range threats. The monk doesn't look at the full picture of the situation, and a fat goblin appears without she noticing it. That's why all of them are dead (the monk is dead inside).


Side characters: I should point out that the side characters are good, and they could be potentially important characters through the series.


Enjoyment 10/10:


I don't want to say much about this, cause that topic is completely my opinion, and I don't think that any argument would completely justify how I am loving this anime. If you didn't like it as much as I liked, whatever, and if you liked it more than me, whatever too.


Overall 9/10:


Goblin Slayer is a solid anime. Its plot is well-written, and its themes are interesting and looks like they are going to be explored. The soundtrack fits the moments and makes a lot of hype to the scenes. What happens always have a reason, and that reason is well stablished during the series. If you like dark shows, or fantasy stories, or dark fantasy stuff, you must check this anime out. 


Well, those were my 1200+ words about everything that I think about Goblin Slayer. Hope you liked it! If you think this was helpful to you, tell it to MAL, clicking the "helpful" button. See you later, in a review of another anime that I want to talk about. Bye.

Goblin Slayer is simply not interesting enough to warrant the attention it receives. Fans of the show seem to think there is a secret agenda set against it that drives any criticism it receives. Perhaps because they want to believe that it is edgy and that they are somehow superior for being able to handle dark content, but this is not the case. Outside of the first ten minutes, Goblin Slayer is a tame and ultimately boring experience.
There are still a few things to like about this show: the adventurers have their limitations and losing seems a possibility in every fight, Goblin Slayer's obsession withgoblins can at times be funny, the action and the party's interactions are usually enjoyable to watch.  These redeeming qualities just aren't enough, however, to overcome a story that seems nonexistent at the best of times and nonsensical at the worst, filled with characters that are either shallow archetypes or simply well-endowed devotees of the titular character.


As a protagonist, Goblin Slayer himself is an effort to watch at times. His limited vocabulary can be a fun quirk, but there's a reason why most main characters talk more - across all mediums of story. Two word sentences and flashbacks can only work so well to garner sympathy, so as a viewer you often find yourself staring emptily at the screen wondering how a scene that requires emotional investment could ever have hoped to pay off. Elf, Lizardman, and Dwarf are likeable enough stock additions to the goblin slaying adventures, but are about as well developed as their names imply.


The arc in Water Town displays the poorest writing Goblin Slayer has to offer. After a repetitive few episodes under the town (with a short break for naked virgin resurrection magic of course), it is confusingly revealed with what I can only chalk up to poor translation that the revered Sword Maiden is responsible for allowing the local goblin incursion to continue because she hoped others would experience her past trauma. This is presented as if it is supposed to be a gratifying plot twist with an emotional confrontation, but it misses the mark entirely. Thus the only tangible development to come out of the four episode arc is that Goblin Slayer wants to make ice cream for his friends, but perhaps that's too dark and edgy for some to appreciate.


While Goblin Slayer has enough superficial entertainment to partially mitigate its lack of a compelling narrative, cookie-cutter characters, and weak ambition, the truth is that the show's quality matters little now that it has become a symbol to rally behind for anyone who thinks of themselves as enlightened just because one brutal scene doesn't put them off a show. The opening episode is ironically a reversed microcosm of the series: it presents itself as a cute adventure show, then jarringly juxtaposes this with brutality as if this will become the norm. The deceptive facade it opens with is actually closer to the truth, however, and even if there were further ruthless spectacles, they would not salvage Goblin Slayer's inadequacy in every regard.

Overall, I enjoyed watching the anime, with the exception of first episode. Going back now, it seems that the first episode was only used for shock value to attract attention from the mass episode. I've watched a lot of other fantasy and adventure animes, with tags in guildhalls such as "Bronze, Silver, etc etc", but I've never seen one in this fashion. Normally, we follow a main protagonist as he makes his way to the top, but this anime doesn't do that. This anime was unique in the sense that it adds a hint of ordinary life. It doesn't attempt to make the protagonist doanything special. He is just an ordinary man killing ordinary creatures, goblins. As for the animation and depiction of scenes, it was quite gruesome, but I believe this risky move will be a progressive one for the anime industry.

A truly brilliant mockery of Fantasy and potentially Isekai (large overlap) tropes. The world is filled with hapless, happy-go-lucky "protagonist" style adventurers, some of them even reaching high rank with this naivety intact. Until something goes, truly, wrong these adventurers always seem to face hardship with optimism and draw strength from these character traits.
In step the Goblins. Inexperienced and Experienced adventurers alike seem to consistently underestimate the evil and capability of these "low level" beasts. There is no glory in slaying a goblin. There is no glory in slaying 100. As such hoards of these beasts are often able to group together and congregate, formingsurprisingly powerful and effective roaming militias, despite their individual low intelligence and strength.


Goblin Slayer is our protagonist. A man who sees this festering, ignored evil and has a single-minded obsession with ending their barbarism. He LIVES Goblin Slaying. He eats solely because his body needs nutrition to kill Goblins. He sleeps solely because he needs to be well-rested to kill Goblins. GS is your standard grim-dark stoic protagonist. Egged on by a terrible past to prevent suffering as much as he, as one man, can.


Throughout the series we learn that, while GS goes underappreciated among the ranks of most adventurers, even those below his skill level, that he has garnered a rather impressive cult following among civilians of the world who have seen the horrors roaming bands of Goblins can inflict upon helpless villages and travellers.


The series mocks overly-positive fantasies where nothing truly goes wrong and the hero and other inhabitants of the world are always safe via last second plot-armour, in the naive and overconfident adventurers found wholesale in the world. The series mocks edgy grim-dark fantasies in the overtly brutal nature of the goblins and GS's character and history. It is interesting seeing a world in which both extreme tropes exist and characters from both interact regularly. I think it also has a positive message about the dangers of dismissing "little" threats for too long.


The majority of negative reviews on this anime accuse it of offering little substance, however to me it seems that, that is the point, as the genre as a whole is over-saturated with power fantasy anime and edgy grim-dark goreporn with little-to-no actual substance or even basic narrative, beyond letting a reader put himself in the place of a powerful protagonist who always comes out on top, regardless of the odds or allow a reader a peek into a cold, uncaring world that does not forgive weakness. GS offers a limited view into both sides of this coin, with the subplot about the perfect seemingly invulnerable "Hero" and the naive adventurers and with the main-plot following GS on his darker crusade against the threat of Goblin-kind.


Other negative reviews complain about the infamous (mostly off-camera, barely graphic in any sense of the word) rape scene. They complain it is "unnecessary" and "adds nothing" to the show. These reviews should be immediately and fully disregarded. The scene is fairly important in cementing the unwavering evil of these creatures that is overlooked due to their weak individual strength by the naive adventurer community as a whole. This complaint is thinly veiled discomfort at darker themes, not a legitimate complaint in any sense. Commonly tacked onto these reviews is a weak complaint from power-trip fans who are upset that the victim doesn't instantly recover from her unspeakable trauma and become a mary-sue of Goblin Slaying.

Goblin Slayer is one of my favorite fantasy series and here's why.
Story
It's bland story of a man killing goblins. But that's what make it so good. It's pretty realistic, I'll explain why in the character later. How goblins are considered trash and such but this man keep killing them because of his traumatizing past. I love that unlike most fantasy anime with RPG from video game themed, this one has the tabletop RPG theme like DnD with their unique classes like mage dwarf, monk dragon, and stuff like that. Like I said, the story is simple, straightforward, but that what makes it so good. Fromthe title I can say I want them to slay goblins, and hey, it delivers.


Art

I can feel that they have decent budget. Few CGs here and there, mostly on Goblin Slayer, maybe to make his armor looks shiny while he's walking. But hey, at least the CG is not a total disappointment like Overlord. Other than the CG part, all other animations look nice and fluid. The fighting scenes are really good.


Sound

One of the few that I like from this anime. Almost all the seiyuu are experienced pros so they work great. Priest Girl especially sounds great. I love her crying and screaming voice and can feel the chill. The music is great, and pretty much serve their purpose. Heart pumping music during fighting scenes, soft music during wholesome scenes. But what I like most? The fighting SFX. The sound of weapons hitting the goblins' flesh, and the sound of the blood spurting, and the arrows flying. They are great and sounds pretty realistic and echoing in my ears. 


Character

This is the best part that I love the most from Goblin Slayer. I especially love that none of the character has an actual name. They're just called Goblin Slayer, Priest Girl, Cow girl, etc. This is one of the series with the "making the MC looks bland so the other side characters shine" type in my opinion. But I'll say this, that Goblin Slayer is a pretty realistic character. I worked in hospital where cops bring their criminals and their victims. Goblin Slayer acts similiar to many other people actually acts after traumatizing event (such as rape victims, and DV victims) where they seems to become stoic and lost interest in many other things. And I also love how, unlike Eren from Attack on Titan that swore he will "kill all titans", Goblin Slayer clearly shows that he knows he won't be able to kill all goblins, but he will at least try to kill as many as he could. And of course, no generic stuff like suddenly getting superpower, or getting power from friendship. The dude use logic, knowledge, and experience, alongside tons of training. He's like budget Batman. And you can see how with interaction he grows with the other characters later on. Good unique main character, that makes the other side characters shine and doesn't feel like this is the "main character is the center of the world + other characters". In here you can feel that... The other characters exists. It doesn't give the "Goblin Slayer and His Bitches" feeling. But more like "this is a group of people with goblin slayer in it".


Enjoyment

I really really enjoy this of course. I give this 9 instead of 10 because, well, in the end the story is pretty bland. He comes, he kill goblins, he finished. I don't say I don't enjoy watching goblins getting pummeled, but in the end I still know "these goblins are getting their butt kicked". So yeah, that's why this get 9 instead of 10.


Overall I give this a 9. Really recommend it. Some parts are indeed a bit disturbing and maybe kinda gory, not something you wanna recommend to people who's new to this kinda series and children of course, but it's enjoyable. The gruesome and disturbing parts just show us about how the world really works and such, and thus should not prevent someone from watching this.

Goblin Slayer is an anime based on a light novel. I haven't read the light novel, but I probably will try to find out how after this review. Like many light novels, it does things on the risque side, but I feel like Goblin Slayer is more mature than most of these light novel adaptations.
Story - Goblin Slayer is a rather typical fantasy world, but pretty detailed in what it focuses on. I love a fantasy story that goes through things slowly with new details that other fantasy works have not expressed before and Goblin Slayer does not stop doing this unlike most anime whichwill discard a chunk of its depth after the first few episodes. 


The focus in this story and its entertainment seems centrally about strategic decisions in hunting and survival. It is one of those anime that is busy explaining a lot of things, but it won't explain action sequences in fine detail like Naruto or something.


The main character is Onna Shinkan, a young priestess who is apparently considered an adult at age 15. She decides to start the story by joining a small group of adventurers. We are not given much background into her decision, but this could be assumed to mean that it is normal for people to become adventurers without much of a second thought. Yet goblins are underestimated in this world. People are given reasons to expect goblins to be less threatening as they are to the extent that the youngest adventurers don't fear going on goblin nest quests. 


The first episode basically is meant to contrast a beginner's experience with goblins to an expert's. Not too unexpected, but presentation goes a long way. But the good thing about the main character is that she is not one to underestimate things, making for a good learner, which is why she works so well with the character of the goblin slayer.


Overall, this is feels more like an event driven story even though the characters are hard to ignore.


Unfortunately, as is indicated by the opening, there are more characters than just the heroine and slayer. I would think that one extra hero would be all right, but instead we have three out of nowhere. This is my main gripe with the show so far, but the world is still better built because of them.


Another odd and potentially negative part is that there is an episode that focuses on two beginner adventures half the time, just to give some un-needed world building and padding out the episode. Episode 7 also ends with some ridiculous padding, but I guess I don't care about this too much so far.


Art - The art design by itself is pretty simple, but the production is great. Simple designs don't detract much in a more grounded story anyway. There are digital effects and maybe 3D models in some places, but it felt like I was watching a much more pure production like 90's anime, but with cleaner art. A lot of female characters besides the priestess have really big breasts, which is a little bit annoying, but I can forgive it since characters are not all that important in this anime.


Sound - In my opinion, the opening and ending themes are very solid. There is a folksy song that tends to play at the beginning of episodes that I find annoying however. 


As for sound effects, it is quite well done. It is a more horrific story after all so sounds are more central than in other anime.


Characters - As I mentioned earlier, the goblin slayer and the priestess have great chemistry as central characters. There is a proper balance of fragility and a super powerful guardian, but the priestess is allowed to be useful most of the times which is better than the vast majority of anime. Most of the show feels more secure because the priestess exists despite Goblin Slayer being the one who is keeping her alive. She is also one of the few female protagonists who really serves as a person anyone connects to better than those stupid brown/black haired male protagonists. I really love having her and Goblin Slayer in the story.


Goblin Slayer is a Vash the Stampede/Rurouni Kenshin kind of figure. He is very fixed on his morals, not too talkative and lives a humble life, but he also has insane skill and power that allows him to exist the way he does. But unlike those two protagonists, Goblin Slayer is shown to have serious limits. He actually seems to consider his priestess a valuable resource in battle, using her powers to end fights far more quickly. But he also is hesitant to keep anyone around with him until he develops more. The story really seems to start in the most significant part of his character development, which is good.


As for the rest of the party, they are introduced around episode 4. They seem like they should be strong considering they are the same rank as people who can slay dragons, but they are pretty pathetic against goblins. They also are characterized pretty poorly and do more to just bring out reasons to flesh out the world. However, they still allow for the story to be entertaining and move forward at a more sustainable pace so they are pretty useful in a meta way.


However, I feel like many female characters are a little too under-developed. The elven girl just doesn't seem to have anything going for her and seems to have a bit of a fluid, unfixed personality.  The girl that Goblin Slayer knows is not explained very clearly besides as being someone waiting for him to come home. The quest clerk is a bit of an exception since she does not have to have a personality, but she is actually quite humanized and you learn a little about how her job works.


There is a witch simply called Majo who feels TOO mysterious and ends up basically having a few pretty minor interactions with the story despite appearing to be important. The most notable thing about her is just her voice acting, which is very odd and would likely be written with many ellipses....


Enjoyment - This is primarily an action anime that should be enjoyable to fans of old-fashioned shounen/seinen. I think it is mostly consistently entertaining, but episodes 4 and 5 felt pretty underwhelming which was almost enough for me to start disliking the show before episode 7 showed me there was still a lot of good scenes to be had.

When I sat down to watch a show about killing goblins titled very plainly, my expectations were low. I wasn't really looking forward to "MC with X special power defeats villain who is going to /take over/destroy/remake the world," but I have to say my doubts were uhh... sidestepped. Goblin Slayer defies expectations entirely, shedding almost all semblance of plot in favor of a twisted amalgamation of slice of life and adventure anime that fails at being a passable version of either.
Traditionally, in an anime that is focused on adventuring and smaller side stories, these stories will have some kind of small plot behind them,generally tying in to one of the characters backgrounds. So far in this show, however, these side stories feel like quests you would get at level 10 in an MMO. "Clear out these ruins/sewers/forests of goblins" does not make for a compelling reason to watch the show, and in fact paints the writers into a corner where the only way to make the episode interesting is for one of the characters to almost die. Maybe some central plot will be introduced to spice up the show a little bit, but in its absence, Goblin Slayer must be carried by its characters, which are in no way strong. 


The character writing in this show is far from the worst I have ever seen, but the lack of a centralized plot forces the spotlight on to various characters and their personalities, highlighting their generic tropes. The dwarf and the elf fight, like in every fantasy show ever. There is a lizard/dragon(?) guy who is the token "wise" character who has one cute thing that they do to make them actually likeable. The priestess is a pushover, and is for some reason frequently used to drive the ecchi scenes in the show. However the main reason everyone is here is Goblin Slayer, who has a character design like I have never seen before. Orcbolg, in the episodes we have seen so far, has actually no personality, and straight up only enjoys killing goblins. The showrunners take this so far that it feels at times the MC has some form of a social disorder. He is unable to pick up social cues, focuses obsessively on one subject, etc. As female characters begin to develop crushes on him, it is more confusing than anything, as Goblin Slayer treats everyone as a means to an end, only VERY rarely showing any semblance of fondness for anyone else. Watching the show ends up being incredibly strange, as it becomes more and more difficult to believe any characters in the show like him at all. 


The sound and art are generic, with my biggest complaint being that the studio sought it fit to CG  Goblin slayer's armor SO frequently. It never fails at taking me out of what little immersion I had, and just comes off as lazy. The fights in this show have run the gambit in quality, but there have been some memorable fights that I wouldn't mind watching again. As for the gore stuff, it personally doesn't bother me. It isn't as bad as some shows that I have seen, but if you are sensitive to that stuff, especially rape, I would skip this. The opening and ending are not very interesting visually, whether you like the song is up to you though. 


In the end, I would still recommend watching it. The show for me is a "so bad its good" type thing, as watching the other characters interact with Goblin Slayer like they aren't talking to a brick wall is somewhat funny to me. Overall, I would give this show about a 4/10, and it would take a miracle from above to improve that score based on the direction of the show.

This is a show which tries to be intense, gritty, and dark. IT IS NONE OF THOSE THINGS. Goblin Slayer is a very weak, underwhelming show. It's known for being very violent, but the violence is rather mild. It only got that reputation by having a rape scene, which only became notorious because rape is more politically incorrect than violence of a non sexual nature.
What makes me say this show isn't dark or intense? The tone is inconsistent. It wastes far too much time with the more goofy, lighthearted scenes. It constantly forgets what it wants to be, and is only interested in pandering toa pathetic audience of neckbeards. And it's definitely isn't intense because there's no action and no suspense. There have been entire episodes with little to no fighting. There's not much of an overarching sense of danger either. They just go around killing goblins, going on the sorts of quests you would see in a video game.


The video game comment brings me to another point. IT TRIES TO HARD TO IMITATE VIDEO GAMES. It just takes generic high fantasy RPG tropes and neither executes them well nor offers anything interesting or new. These video game tropes do not translate well into an anime medium. These tropes actually work in video games, because they combine gameplay with some real world connections, while there's no reason to do that in an anime series where there's no gameplay to facilitate. It's a pointless way of ruining any chance the show had at being believable. And yes, fantasy has to be believable. It has to be immersive to allow the audience to suspend their disbelief. Goblin Slayer acts too much like a video game, and it has absolutely no immersion whatsoever.


Let's not forget that it looks like shit. What in the goddamn hell is the purpose of animating the titular character with that ATROCIOUS fucking CGI model every time he appears? Even when he's just standing there or walking around, they use CGI. It doesn't make sense. Why can't you animate a guy in armor LITERALLY JUST WALKING AROUND? Plus it's really choppy. The CGI is insanely choppy, and so is the 2D animation. It's like watching a slideshow. I guess that's typical of most anime, so I won't take too many points off for that. Good animation is extremely rare in anime. Goblin Slayer is just as lazy as the rest of the garbage in the pile. The character design and settings are nothing to write home about either. Just your standard medieval setting. The elf girl is your standard elf, the dwarf is your standard dwarf, and there's that one chick with big tits for good measure. The female characters are cute. The priestess girl is frankly adorable, but I couldn't give less of a shit about that because this is supposed to be a gritty action show.


That brings me to the characters. They're all boring. Goblin Slayer is a guy who slays goblins because he has a tragic backstory involving him seeing goblins do bad things which traumatized him and made him want to slay them. That's not even a proper tragic backstory. It could not be less generic. And he could not be less boring and flat. In fact, he's a goofy and laughable character. He literally eats and drinks through a helmet visor. He's like a really lame Doomguy. He even has the word slayer in his name, like the Doom Slayer of the 2016 reboot. There's just nothing charming, unique, or complex about anyone in the show. And why does the elf girl, who's thousands of years old, act so childish?


Let's talk about the PREMISE of the show. A guy who only kills hoards of extremely low level, weak enemies, despite being a powerful warrior whose extensive fighting experience has gained him a high rank as an adventurer. and made him famous. LAME. Why would I want to watch a show about someone who only kills one type of enemy? I want some variety. And why would I watch a show about a guy killing such weak enemies? Doomguy is badass because he kills badass demons. Goblin Slayer is like watching a show about a janitor squashing cockroaches with his broom. There's no sense of danger. Sure, there's an ogre, but the main focus is on weak enemies.


I'll admit, this show's premise would be a great premise for a comedy anime that parodies fantasy tropes. As I already mentioned, the titular character is pretty funny, being someone who eats and drinks through his armor. BUT IT'S SUPPOSED TO BE A SERIOUS SHOW. I'll emphasize that it's *supposed* to be serious. In reality, it's hard to take seriously. And that's one merit of the show. It can be fun if you're watching it just to make fun of it. The first episode had me cracking up. It was just so obvious who was about to get raped. It was like watching a pornstar deliver over-the-top forced one liners in a cheesy porno. But after that it tones down so much that it loses its comedic value.


Now there's one thing I like about this show. I like the OP. It simply sounds pleasing to me. But the rest of the music is underwhelming, so it doesn't gain any points for that.


What could this show have done well? Well, it could have had one of the women who was actually raped by goblins become the Goblin Slayer. It is rather misogynistic, isn't it? A male hero has to save these helpless women, and a puppy-like, obedient girl follows the Slayer around and tries to help him. As I mentioned, the show could have been good if it took itself less seriously. Even if it weren't a straight up comedy, it could have embraced its silly premise and focused on just being insanely action packed and over the top. But it found a terrible balance where it's too serious to be fun, yet too silly to take seriously.


If you want some dumb, mindless, schlocky action, this still isn't the show for you. I love mindless, over the top action. Watch Fist of the North Star for that. This show is too visually unappealing, inconsistent, and strangely devoid of action for that.

Anyways, what I wantedto bring is the things about Goblin slayer that I felt a lot of people missed out or had fly right over their head. Here they are:


1. Goblin slayer defies conventional RPG tropes

Everyone who plays and knows RPGs usually think that goblins are petty, low level enemies who are really easy to kill. Welp, not even the noobiest of adventurers could do much against the goblins. Rather they got themselves killed by creatures that allegedly have the intelligence of children (ha... that says a lot about the adventurer group).

2. The NSFW scene and the perspective on Goblins

Yeah, everyone knows about this. It might as well not even be a spoiler. Anyways, whilst I know a huge amount of people hate the anime for this very scene. I sometimes feel like people forget that the scene is intentionally made to be disgusting. It gives us a reason to hate goblins, to believe that they are completely evil monsters. By no means is it meant to encourage rape. Not sure why anyone would come to that conclusion, since the scene is meant to do the exact opposite (Unless you have a fetish for that)



3. The whole situation with goblins raiding villages

This is the one I think most people miss out on. Yeah, we all know why goblins raid villages, what on earth could we be possibly missing? It's that this whole raiding thing is actually a representation of the Dark ages (There is probably a lot of people who have watched Goblin slayer but don't even know what the Dark ages were; if you do, good on ya, if otherwise, google it). During this time, Raiders would always pillage defenseless villages and DO THE EXACT SAME THINGS THAT GOBLINS DID IN GOBLIN SLAYER. Raiders would, steal money, steal livestock, steal food, steal equipment, rape/kidnap women, kill men and children and all sorts of other dark crap you can think of. The Goblins in goblin slayer are no different to those raiders.

People often complain about CG in anime. I never really understood why people hate it so much. It has always seemed like a preconceived notion to me. Anyways, I believe that CG wasn't over done in Goblin slayer. The animations themselves weren't to bad either (albeit, CG was usually used in short scenes). At least they weren't overused AND poorly animated like the CG in Overlord where soldiers literally bounced off shields by charging at them (because physics)


Sound 7/10

Nothing exceptional, but nothing bad either. I don't have much to say about the sound effects since it mostly consists of stabbing and slashing sounds.


The music is not to my tastes, but this is completely subjective. I tried not to let my view on the music affect the rating here too much, since, in my experience, it didn't seem to affect the scenes too much.


Character 7/10

I struggled to rate this one the most. A lot of people will think that the characters are boring or are cardboard cutouts of stereotypical anime tropes. What made me give Characters a balanced  rating was because of the voice acting and the character backstory; which kinda negate the negative of the seemingly bland at first glance personalities all the characters have. 


The voice acting was pretty darn good in my opinion. The way the characters screamed and tried fighting back the goblins seemed at least somewhat realistic to me. I know a lot of people might disagree with me on that, but that's only because I have been in fights where people badly wounded each other. So yeah, I believe that people do scream like that in these kind of fights


Backstory is a quite a sidetrack for me since I read the manga after watching the anime, my opinion will be slightly biased and not representative of the anime here. I can see how some people view him this way, since his backstory is far better elaborated upon in the manga, but not the anime.


Enjoyment 6/10

Wouldn't exactly say this was enjoyable watch because of the graphic content (unless you have a fetish for that NSFW scene). Which does make sense, since the anime is supposed to be as disturbing as it could possibly be. I dare say that the goblins are doing a good job at that. Being a very controversial anime, I tried to stray away from the things people often complained about. I focused more on the representation of things such as how goblins are evil (obviously) and that goblins raiding villages is normal since the exact same thing happened during the Dark ages. 


I realise I'm being a massive hypocrite here in saying that people missed the point of goblin slayer since I myself have also skipped over many details. The motive for this review was just to provide another perspective to Goblin Slayer. Pls I beg you, don't sue me T-T

Fair warning that this anime has a lot of gore/violence in it. 
What I like about this show is that it knows what it is and what it wants to keep being. A lot of shows try to be several things at once so they can appeal to larger audience which causes them to have a good start and concept but fail later on and drop in quality of their story. But that is not case with Goblin Slayer.
This anime is not a must-watch but it is good and definitely worth your time if you do watch it. I've seen two types of peoplewith views on this anime, either they love it or they hate it. So you should check it out and see which side of the spectrum you're in. The first episode itself will let you know whether you want to continue watching it or drop it then and there.


Also to note that the author of the story is a huge fan of Dungeons & Dragons so expect a few characters and details in the world to be based on that.


STORY - 6/10 

 Story isn't too complicated and fairly basic. Something bad happened in the protagonist's past and now he has dedicated his life to slaying Goblins. Hence the name - Goblin Slayer. Now it might not seem much but the show knows what it is and what it wants to do so it's pretty much guaranteed that it will be consistent till the end. The shows uses this concept nicely to bring in new characters which do not feel out of place or random. It is a lot like a video game where there is a guild, you form a party and go on quests.


ART and ANIMATION - 7/10

 The art isn't the most unique but still looks good. The animation is clean and looks good and feels fluid during the action scenes. Although there is a random use of CGI in the less important scenes like when the characters are just walking (without any dialogue) and it is only there for a second or two (most people won't even notice it but it feels random and serves no purpose). But they don't use it in the important scenes so it shouldn't be a problem.


SOUND - 5/10

 The sound is alright nothing much to say there. Fits in well and doesn't feel out of the place but is easily forgettable. The opening and ending look visually good but song wise they are okay.


CHARACTER - 8/10

 The strongest aspect of the show. There hasn't been many episodes so don't expect some major character development. But each and every character is very likable (except the Goblins). The protagonist isn't your usual in a fantasy/harem setting. He is however the guy with a tragic past and looking for revenge type. But he acts different from characters like that. He has one goal set in mind and nothing can distract him from that. Money? Women?Relationships?Happiness? He doesn't care about any of that, he's not interested in/want anything in life. The Goblin Slayer only wants to wake up everyday - kill goblins -go to sleep - repeat. Honestly, it is a bit refreshing to see a main character like this. The others characters too have their own goals and have good chemistry with each other.


ENJOYMENT - 8/10

 It is very fun to watch, especially the action and characters. The action scenes when they're killing Goblins are explained very well and not just randomly swinging around your weapon.


OVERALL - 7/10

 It isn't very unique but a certainally good watch. I personally find it good and I'm definitely going to read the manga and the light novels after finishing the anime.

Goblin Slayer is a refined piece of fantasy anime, making use of an unabashedly generic fantasy world to tell an ultra-focused and entertaining story about killing goblins.
The series is memed out as being a gore-filled rape fest, but rape isn't so much an on-screen occurrence as it is an ever-present threat. When you see your favorite Elf character being pinned down by goblins there's an added layer of fear because you know the goblins don't just want to murder her.
One interesting part about Goblin Slayer is that there is almost "anti-world building" in the sense that the viewer is assumed to automatically understand most ofthe fundamental aspects of the world. There's a kingdom with knights and wizards, but there's also the threat of demons and all of the monsters that serve them. Adventurers go to a guild in town and take quests to slay monsters. The viewer knows everything there is to know about this world immediately. The characters don't even have names, they are referred to by their titles or classes.


The show is a bit smarter than it lets on but nothing brilliant. There are some interesting themes. I specifically enjoyed the "Wanderer" speech Goblin Slayer makes, comparing himself to a high tier goblin who has suffered, but survived and learned from his adversity. We see this theme pop up in the finale when the Priestess resists the begging of the Goblin Lord.


The real enjoyment of the show comes not from an imaginative or unique setting, but from the titular Goblin Slayer doing what he does best, slaying goblins. He is grouped up with a generic but lovable band of adventurers and sent off on quests to achieve that end. Everything is paced near-perfectly to make this show incredibly binge-friendly. The animation is slick, the gory fight scenes are a beauty to watch (especially because of how easy it is to hate these little green fucks), the music is fitting. It all works together in an amazing way.


Goblin Slayer does what anime should do - it entertains. Don't expect anything life changing, but do expect an extremely enjoyable ride.

Art: 5/10
Mix of traditional-style and cgi elements. For the most part, human anatomy and proportions looked fine. Non-human characters checked out too. Clear use of shortcuts in a lot of the animation. Heavy use of selective framing, using cgi for a majority of anything that wasn't a static picture, dropping or low amount of frames for fast movement or action. Overall, unhappy with the below average animation. 


Characters: 7/10

The character designs were on point and were adapted nicely. Character personalities fit pretty well too. Goblin Slayer felt like Goblin Slayer, but that's only saying so much since the dude's a monotone hunk of metal. Plot & Development: 7/10

The manga was more or less adapted 1 for 1. I don't recall there being any filler segments that I haven't seen from the manga. There were some changes in the presentation of the narrative to make things more clear which was fine. Overall, things happened as they should have, things happened when they should have, and things were presented well enough to make me appreciate the whole effort.


Music: 5/10

Music was generic guitar strings. Unmemorable. Soundboard was acceptable. No sound design to note. I liked the OP and ED. 


Conclusion: 7/10

Overall: 5/10

Average adaptation that I was originally questioning the necessity of; why adapt it if it's going to be such poor quality? Eventually came to tolerate it because of the ending scene. Overall, average art, below average animation, and decent character building because of its good adaptation of certain characters and Goblin Slayer's development.

If you're reading this, I'm sure you've heard about some of the controversies associated with the thing depicted in "Goblin Slayer". If not, then you should be warned that some people have been offended and put off to the series due to graphic scenes of violence and rape. This anime got a bad rap so fast and some people were too blind to get over these scenes to get to the great story-telling it has behind it. 
DISCLAIMER: This is my second review ever and I'm sure you may hear these points somewhere else. This review may also contain SPOILERS
"Eventually, everyone reaches their limit, whetherit be an adventurer or a hero"

STORY 8/10


Goblin Slayer starts in a fantasy world, full of adventurers and demons. The cliche world is what makes Goblin Slayer good. The creator has taken the classic tale of a hero defeating the demon lord and thrown it into the background. Instead, the story focuses on the "Goblin Slayer" working as an everyday adventurer. Some would argue that there is no coherent story, as episodes are usually one-offs but are referred to later on. This is a misconception, as the story revolves around the Goblin Slayer's backstory and his journey to recovering from the horrors he had faced during childhood. 


The Hero and her party eventually slay the demon lord in the world and the world is freed. The kingdoms rejoice and celebrate the victory, but Goblin Slayer pays no attention to this. The anime shows him preparing for his next mission. This is because the author wanted to show that the world moves onward after the demon lord is defeated, and Goblin Slayer is a character who knows that the most. The threats of the world have not changed, and the story does a perfect job of depicting that. 


The theme of PTSD (Post Traumatic Stress Disorder) is also brought into the series, as scenes depicting Goblin Slayer's past are shown. The story shows these gruesome scenes to help define the character and build the world. Goblin Slayer lives with the constant fear of the terror of the goblin race and as the story progresses and he builds a party of his own, his PTSD progressively fades. The story of healing creates a relatable character. Goblin Slayer, the anime, shows that focusing on minor points in the plot help build up a great anime. There are few people who understand the threat of the goblins, and because of that, they go unnoticed and the people who live through the terrors that the goblins bring are forgotten as well. The previous Hero, the sword maiden, lives with these scars both physically and mentally and meets with Goblin Slayer, knowing that he is one of the only people who could feel the same way as her. Displaying the helplessness of those with traumatic pasts help to define how the world views goblins, even if the person is the saviour of the world.


The story and character development go above and beyond, especially in episode 10. In this episode, the farm girl sits with Goblin Slayer under the stars. She speaks to him about the future, although he doesn't understand what she means by this. The farm girl has been previously introduced as a minor character with little involvement in the Goblin Slayer's work but is connected to his past. The following scene helps illustrate the sadness she feels for the Goblin Slayer and that, though she is cheerful, she understands the world as much as Goblin Slayer does. She begins a monologue explaining the life of adventurers. Adventurers will eventually grow old and tire. Eventually, the toughest people reach their limit. Though the people celebrate the victory against the Demon Lord, these days won't last forever. The Goblin Slayer will eventually tire and will perish as well, and this thought frightens her the most.


ART 9/10


The art for the world of Goblin Slayer is superb. Details in the armour, weapons, and even the environment help to create an atmosphere of terror that the creator was aiming for when writing the novels. While some complain about the CGI of goblin slayer or the goblins, I have found that it works well in this series. The evergrowing overuse of CGI in series has created a stigma behind its use altogether. Granted, there is no denying there usually isn't a need for it but CG animations can create a feel in scenes like a battle that regularly drawn animations cannot. The weight of a swing and the movement of a character is easier to depict to develop a sense of a well-choreographed battle. While it isn't necessarily needed for the Goblin Slayer, it does its job well. The clothing of the characters and their equipment help define their roles well, both in the party and with their personality. 


On to the controversial scenes. These scenes depict the gruesome killings of adventurers and the rape and torture endured by the characters who come into contact with these goblins. I understand why some would find this offensive, but they play a crucial role in creating the atmosphere of the series. Do I think there is another way to depicting the horrors of the goblin race? Probably, but do I think there is a better way of doing so? No.


CHARACTER 9/10


The theme of growth and change is especially relevant in this series. A common complaint I've seen from others is that the Goblin Slayer character has no emotion and that he's a "brick wall" when it comes to personality. The characters in Goblin Slayer also don't have names and are referred to by their respective classes such as a priest or dwarf mage. While Goblin Slayer, the character, doesn't do much on his own to create a personality, his dialogue, actions, and his backstory do. The Goblin Slayer is presented as a quiet high-ranked adventurer, who is sometimes questioned for his status as the only kills low-level Goblins. As the story progresses, we see how his character is intelligent and capable as a warrior and that he rarely speaks because of his cold exterior. We are shown bits and pieces of his past to develop his reason for fighting and show the regrets he has. Goblin Slayer is a character that believes he must atone for his failures, as he could not prevent the rape and killing of his sister from the Goblins and although he has shown the capability of a skilled warrior, he too as admitted that he fears the goblins, but he hides it in battle. 


The characters around Goblin Slayer help to change his perspective on the world and grow as a person little by little. His party helps him open up to others and begin to forget about his traumatic past. The Farm Girl helps to define what is left of his humanity and shows that he has a limit.

Every once in a while there comes a series that becomes the highlight of the season. You keep seeing memes and discussions and you ask yourself, why is this popular? Am I missing out on something, or is this show as bad as it seems?  Spoiler alert: In this case, it is.
Story: 
Goblin Slayer is a pretty simple show. It’s about a dude who just wants to go around slaying goblins. The story isn’t your typical isekai, since it’s in a fantasy setting to begin with, but it features ranks and missions that heavily remind you of this genre. However, the story doesn’t goanywhere. You keep asking yourself, is there a point to my suffering? Unfortunately the answer is no. Through all these episodes, we’re just watching Goblin Slayer going on missions to slay goblins with a bunch of forgettable characters again and again. And if there are a few episodes with no missions, there’s literally no plot. We just see some characters wandering around doing nothing, instead of deepening our understanding of the characters. If the characters don't have meaningful interactions or emotional depth during the screentime then you can't seem to care about them or the rest of the guild. There’s absolutely nothing to follow. You just wait for some progression that never comes.


Characters:


HOLY SHIT if you thought the plot was bad then prepare to go even lower. Goblin Slayer, our main character, is so bland it’s comical. He only thinks about goblins, and his vocabulary simply consists of the words ‘’goblins’, ‘’yes’’ and ‘’I see’’. His VA must have had a ball while reading the script! Goblin Slayer is supposed to be a tragic character because his life was basically ruined by goblins. Nonetheless, you simply can’t feel bad for him because his past is described in a very vague and half-assed manner. It’s as if the author was on his third glass of wine like ‘’Oh so the MC has to kill goblins but there needs to be a reason. Hmm what could it be? Let’s write the most generic scenario possible and leave out any details’’. But I digress, let’s get on with the rest of the cast. The Priestess is our secondary main character. She’s the typical meek and mild character, but she proves herself useful with her spells during combat. Another character we have is the Cow Girl, she’s a friend of Goblin Slayer from the past. She lives in a remote farm, and she’s the caring older sister type, who is simply waiting around for Goblin Slayer for days on end. There’s also the High Elf, who is an annoying tsundere with no reason for existing, Guild girl, whose sole role is to gives out quests, Lizardman and Dwarf, who keep arguing with the Elf girl for no reason. As you might have noticed, none of these characters have a personal name. You simply call them by the term that indicates their role, appearance or usefulness. While not intentional, I think this really helps you understand how one-dimensional and forgettable the cast is. I wish I could expand on each character in the guild, but they're so cliche and underdeveloped it's impossible.


Another problem I have with the show is its gratuitous rape scenes. In the series, the goblins are so depraved and hateful that they rape female characters. However, the writing is incoherent in this aspect. If you’re doing a show where you agree that rape is awful, then you should commit to its conseqences by either denoting how traumatizing it is OR by simply not sexualizing girls so much, to the point of trivializing the issue. Hell, there was a rape scene in the first episode, and in the beginning of the second one there was already totally unnecessary fanservice! There's even a female character that was raped by goblins yet she's a walking fanservice-- an extremely seductive character with huge breasts that defy gravity. As a side note, I am not saying fanservice is bad. If you're an anime fan you've seen your fair share of boobs and ass shots, for better or for worse. My issue lies with the particular setting and how lightly it's treated.


Overall:


Goblin Slayer is a badly written show. Even if its theme is supposed to be Goblin Slayer’s humanization through creating bonds, it ultimately falls flat because all characters fail to have a personality or any meaningful interaction with each other. If you can’t like or relate with the characters, you can’t root for them or feel bad for them. The animation and OST are the only redeeming features, although they're nothing outstanding. Unless you’re interested in random combat quests with no regard for the characters, I would recommend staying away from this.

*Fair warning first* This review may contain some spoilers so please keep in mind. This is also going to be my first review so bear with me
     A lot of anime in the Fantasy genre or Isekai anime in a fantasy setting(or basically almost every fucking isekai at this point) have been pretty oversaturated with the easy going atmosphere and overpowered main characters. That Time I got Reincarnated as a Slime is a pretty falls into this category quite nicely, with the goblins being kind and tame creatures.
