      Goblin Slayer is a Dark Fantasy anime about a man that forms a party of adventurers to hunt goblins. The title is pretty self-explanatory right? It's got everything you'd want in a Dark Fantasy. You got blood and gore, lots of action, and it's also got some rape...I mean cute waifus ecks dee. \n
      There was a lot of controversy at the beginning of the show on how it depicted the pretty graphic rape scene in , which made a lot of Social Justice Warriors on twitter go into a frenzy. "If you like this show then you're just a stupid edgelord that enjoys harassing women and minorities". The main criticism I see about the show is that its needlessly edgy on how scenes of sexual assault is nothing but empty shock factor, and I think that's pretty fucking retarded. Let me go a little in depth just in case there are some triggered SJWs reading my awful review who dislike the show for the reasons I just said.\n
       Episode 1 was a fantastic episode in my opinion, even though it felt like my dick kept retracting from inside my body most of the times, but that was the whole point. It set the tone incredibly early. It showed us that even though goblins may not look as dangerous, they're actually violent and terrifying creatures. They attack villages,killing farmers and destroying crops, while also kidnapping and raping women so that they can reproduce, and they can become even stronger, turning into hobgoblins, or even a Goblin Lord. I also got chills sent down my spine when Goblin Slayer first appeared.\n
      The characters aren't really anything that special in his show, except for Goblin Slayer, who is one of the most badass characters I've seen in an anime. At the same time hes only a silver ranked adventurer, which is only the 3rd highest rank, which means he's not overpowered. I want to actually go into depth about Goblin Slayer himself. The show doesn't really give him a decent backstory, but it gives him an incredibly strong purpose. As a child, he literally watched his sister get raped and murdered by goblins, which makes him develop the most extreme amount of hatred towards something I think I've ever seen. That's all he talks about is killing goblins. He's killed so many for so long that he's gained an incredible amount of knowledge about them, which not only makes him badass, but really entertaining to watch. The way he plans out clearing a goblins nest and all his creative and efficient ways of killing goblins are so fun to watch. Every situation he is put in, no matter how dire it may be, he is always calm and collected. He is the main driving force of this show. \n
       All in all, once you get past that stuff, this show is a pretty entertaining watch and was actually a breath of fresh air I wouldn't recommend it to just anyone for obvious reasons. On the other hand if you enjoy your dark fantasy and also a huge fan of Berserk, then I highly recommend you give this a watch. This show is graphic and is not for everyone. This is not your typical happy adventure story, and it does a good job showing that in the first episode.
Goblin Slayer is the best anime of 2018, and one of the best that I have ever seen. This is just my opinion, if you disagree that's fine, we are all entitled to our own opinions. 
The show takes place in a fairly standard world of magic and adventure, but the elements that are focused on is what really sets it apart from the rest. Instead of focusing on a 'big bad' (demon lord, lich, enemy kingdom,ect.) it takes a realistic view on what are usually minion enemies or pests. The way in which the goblins are portrayed as vile pests is the most accurate and faithful portray that I have seen. The show does a great job of making you detest these creatures without making them out to be the most dangerous or evil threat to the world. There is a fair amount of graphic material, not only gore but adult themes. The graphic nature of the show is not graphic just for the sake of it or for shock value, rather it is a faithful depiction of the vile creatures that goblins are. 


The magic of the world is that of classic D&D. There is a limit to how many spells you can cast per day and you gain more spells over time through leveling up. This setup allows for magic to be used without making it too powerful and forces the casters to be creative to optimize the effectiveness of its use.


The main charter, Goblin Slayer, is a well designed charter who goes through a believable and interesting development through out the show. He is not particularly special in any way. He is not powerful because he's a 'chosen one' or because he found a great magic item, in fact he is only extremely effective against goblins.This because he has dedicated his life to studying them and coming up with specific ways to fight them. He pays attention to the world around him and uses whatever he learns to better fight goblins. He is simply a broken man who wishes to kill goblins to prevent what happened to him from happening to others. During the first season he meets others who work with him and through this he begins to heal as a person.


The introduction of new charters feels natural and flows nicely with the plot. The progression of the story is kept at a good pace with very little filler and a good amount of action. There are new types enemies and situations that keep things interesting without feeling forced. 


I have seen many complaints about aesthetics of the show, but I'm not sure why. There are some scenes where bigger more complex creatures are rendered using CGI, but that is something common when trying to make large, complex, and detailed creatures. I agree that these elements still have a way to go to be more seamlessly blended with non CGI elements, but I think it has come far even from just a few years ago. Despite issues with the CGI elements, I quite like the art style of the show.


I think that this show is a wonderful look at enemies that are normally overlooked, with charters that are normal adventures (more or less). The world built in this show is realistic and balanced in respect magic, enemies, and the individual strength of charters. I applaud this show for not shy away from the graphic material naturally stemming from the vile enemies in it, and approaches it in as tasteful a manner possible. The result were charters with believable motivation and enemies that were a real threat.

Goblin Slayer strays away from the usual kinds of shows in its genre. Goblin Slayer illustrates this by displaying the tragic outcomes of those who thought lightly of the low leveled goblins and ended up paying dearly.The show continues to contrast this with a knowledgeable and overall competent protagonist who places great emphasis on even the smallest of details to ensure that tragic outcomes will at leastnot occur from slight mishaps or hubris.

As someone coming to this anime after having binge read the first 30 chapters of the manga, I can say my initial impression of the adaption was all-in-all a sense of utter disappointment. I read through the first 25 chapters without break and finished the last 5 available after a short intermission, though when faced with the anime I had to take a break after the first episode, and lost almost all interest in this after the second.
To start of with the manga itself felt like a action/drama filled story delving into both adventures and the dark past of the main character, but with theanime I found the story lacking on both of those fronts. The main character himself jumps between normal animation and CG animation throughout the episodes in an unattractive way, and most of the entertaining action scenes from the manga have either been cut out, shortened, or changed to have the main character using only his bow instead of "time consuming to edit" melee-combat that truly exhibited the main character as a well rounded and experienced combatant.


A lot of the inner monologues and conversations between some the the characters meant to help lay out and develop their personalities have been cut out, leaving the characters to be more of lack luster husks of what they were shown as in the manga. Overall a lot of stuff is just omitted, speed up, or watered down in the anime for sake of time, causing the overall pace of the anime to be a lot faster than the manga in a bad way.


In terms of art and sound everything overall is okay, besides for the lazy use or CG in a way that doesn't really show off how good CG can be in the proper hands, as well as some areas where music is put in that overall just DOES NOT fit the dark fantasy atmosphere that this story is supposed to have.

When I first heard that this was getting an anime I was skeptical. Lots of novels and manga with very graphic content often get toned down a lot once they hit the big screen, for obvious reasons. While they didn't show all of the images that the novel or manga may have shown, they managed to capture the same level of brutality through smart editing. 
I would love to give the art a higher rating than 7, it really deserves about a 9 but it just looks so out of place seeing a group of 2D characters being led by a grey 3D blob. Iget that using 3D models is much easier and time efficient than fully drawing and animating the 2D character, it's still gonna cost them the points. \n
Overall, super pumped for the rest of the season. This is the one to watch for all the action junkies out there.

To begin, I'll state my biases; I love Goblin Slayer. Not the anime, but the Novels and Manga. The anime, which as of today I am dropping, has disgusted me in its handling of the source material. I'll talk more about it later.
Let's talk about the animation, first and foremost. Like always Whitefox is doing a good job with their animation. The hiccup here is Goblin Slayer, who for whatever reason is CG most of the time when he's moving. The animation is bad and it sticks out like a sore thumb because of how it's shaded compared to the rest of the scenery andshow. It pulls you out, but I could ignore it because when it matters he's fully drawn and looks amazing.


From here, I talk about the story. The story *WOULD* be great, were it not for the blaring issue I will talk about later. Before we get into potential spoilers, I'll give a basic synopsis; Goblin Slayer slays goblins. It's simple, concise and to the point. The way it should be. He finds other people, and goes to kill goblins. That's it. Why? Because the show skips all the character development that should be there, seemingly taking the title of the novels as the point of the show, and skipping anything that would flesh out the characters.


The music in the show is great, and the sound design is well done. During fights it sounds almost like music out of DOOM, making for an epic murder-fantasy vibe. This is deliberate and well done, exactly the way that I'd have wanted it to go when I was first reading the manga months ago.


The anime itself should be very enjoyable to anyone coming in completely blind. You wouldn't know the glaring flaws with the story because it skips over it completely as each fight/raid/battle is more or less separated from one another. You could cut out the dozens of inconsequential quests you do in an RPG, for example, and wouldn't lose anything regarding the story and any viewers or people you were telling the story to wouldn't notice or care because you still touched on the important stuff. The important stuff, that the director has so tactlessly decided to scrub from the anime for God knows why.


I don't know if I should call this a spoiler or not, because at this point the anime has completely skipped it but for the sake of those who are completely new to the series I'll be vague about it. The climax of the first volume, which is what is in the first four episodes with the fifth being side-stories from volume 4 that take place during vol.1, is a large-scale battle between the adventurers of the town and an army of goblins. This fight is supposed to be the cumulation of everything Goblin Slayer has done throughout the first volume, building relationships with his party and his work for the guild. It shows how much Guild Girl cares about Goblin Slayer, as she begs the guild to produce a special quest for this event. It shows that Goblin Slayer has things that he cares about, and further develops his motivation. Finally, it acts as the ultimate tone-setter for wider series as a whole, as we see a large clash between silver-ranks and goblins that are equal if not greater in power to them. It is a MASSIVE plot point in the series and while it's not referenced much later (not until vol.3 if I remember correctly) it shows that GS has attachments to the people around him and the world. Why they would skip this is beyond me, but I can't get over it and it caused me to drop the series no more than seven minutes into episode six where they show the start of the next entire volume.


I can't recommend this show, because it treats a story that I genuinely love with irreverence and actively ignores the best aspects of it. If you're interested, skip it and read the manga instead. If you like the manga, read the light novels. While they're not for those with weak constitutions, they are fantastically written and they are among the works that influence my own style of storytelling.

How do I even begin... This show is trying to tell a story without the use of plot, which is impossible. Even The ALO arc of SAO did a better job with plot than this excuse of a show. Almost 1/2 way through the show and all that has happened is: Goblin slaying, goblin slaying, goblin slaying, a meeting, a meal, goblin slaying, irrelevant characters adventure, goblin slaying and more goblin slaying. There might have been a little bit of goblin slaying in there also. 
Next, the characters. These characters don’t even have names for crying out loud. Bland, cookie cutter, generic characters.
Art. Decent backgroundand character design. But the CGI for Goblin Slayer is just lazy. There have been characters with way more intricate designs animated by hand in the past.\n
Sound. Garbage ost garbage op garbage ed.\n
Enjoyment. Nonexistent.\n
Overall: Terrible show. Drastically overrated just because of the gore (there have been shows with more gore in the past).

Now I have read all the current manga chapters available, so my thoughts are based both on the anime itself and how it compares itself to the manga.
I like how the first episode is an introduction to the world and how dark it can be. No kiddie show here. Second episode we get some needed backstory and what drives the Slayer. And in the third episode we get character development and world building.
I am extremely pleased on how the anime is turning out so far, it is heavily censored of course but they still show more than I thought they would. The boss fight inthe latest episode was a bit of a let down, compared to the manga, but still, not bad. \n\n
I can not wait to see the rest of the show, depending on how well they adapt the upcoming fights my score might change, but for now this is without a doubt a 10 for me.

'Edgy' is defined by Daria as, "when middle-brow, middle-aged profiteers are looking to suck the energy, not to mention spending-money, out of the 'quote-unquote' 'youth culture.' So they come up with this fake concept of seeming to be dangerous when every move they make is the result of market research and a corporate master plan." This description is sardonic, but is nonetheless fitting for Goblin Slayer.
I don't think it even qualifies as a spoiler at this point to mention the pilot features a rape scene. Fair enough, it's an ultra-violent carnage romp like Berserk then, right? Well, no, not in the least. The rest ofthe show is a bog standard fantasy show with absolutely nothing else to surprise the viewer. It's insulting to consider how much controversy swirled around a show literally featuring an ice cream episode.


The fact of the matter is Goblin Slayer was a bait-and-switch; it attracted a crowd with an edgy first episode only to spend the rest of a bland season trotting around its gimmick of 'he only kills goblins' ad nauseum. The supporting cast range from trying and failing to connect with Mr. Slayer to just being flat and largely ignored. The show even tries to dip its toe into deeper topics like coping with trauma only to shy away to the tune of, you guessed it, 'he only kills goblins.' 


Don't watch it. Don't bring it up to your friends. Don't even make it a meme as a bait-and-switch show. Just let it fade into obscurity where it belongs and where, without it being disengenous and portraying itself as an over-the-top orgy of sex and violence, it would have been from the start.

This might be one of the worst animes ever created. The first episode sets some expectations that ultimately end up betrayed. The first half of the show in general is alright, but it goes downhill from there into one of the most disappointing and nonsensical and anti-climatic last episodes I've ever seen.
There is absolutely NO story and the entire thing is full of last minute asspulls, contradictions, and predictable conveniences. The only reason it gets good reviews at all are from kids who like edginess, but it even fails THERE as well (pretty much only the first episode is edgy) ultimately leaving something that endsup with no redeeming qualities.

I came to watch Goblin Slayer after the big fallout that the first episode provoked in most of the left wing faction of the anime fandom, only to be disappointed most of the time that I watched an episode of this anime. Some spoilers ahead, you are warned.
Story (6/10):
Simple, a young Priestess goes in a quest to defeat some goblins with an inexperienced party, but reality came to them when the rest of her party is killed and raped, and she's only saved by a mysterious armored man who comes by the name of Goblin Slayer. This single episode is what attracted a lot ofnegativity from the left, criticizing the rape scenes as in we haven't seen it before, let me remind you that a couple of weeks later, SAO Alicization had rape scenes and nobody screamed like a retard and behaved like a snowflake.


This episode alone and the wasteland that left is what attracted me in order to offer a right-wing counterbalance point of view and to try to defend the show, just to keep me disappointing more and more, because since watching Ep-1, I expected an edgy anime which revolved on gross scenes just for the sake of it and not some generic D&D adventures that was, well, more than 50% of the series. And CR even dared to put a "trigger warning" for having "disturbing scenes", they should have put a trigger warning cautioning the viewer to not get bored. (Note: I condemn every single act of rape that this show or other ones have, be it fiction or IRL, for the ones who will try to accuse me as a "rape glorifier")


While Goblin Slayer has its moment of intense gore scenes, like in the city's sewers arc and the final arc with all the adventurers. GS was for the most part a boring anime with no sense of direction nor a high development of the characters' personalities, which I could forgive in an anime without sense of direction, like Lucky Star.


Art (7/10):

White Fox is a good studio and worked relatively well with the animation and the design of the characters, the Dwarf and the Lizard are very well designed, so is the Priestess and the High Elf who are very cute and attractive. My only complaint here is the constant use of CG to Goblin Slayer's movement, it feels completely out of sorts and actually hinders the fluid motions of the other characters.


Sound (5/10):

The OP is very mediocre, boring and uninteresting, it doesn't give you the emotions of an Adamas (SAO Alicization), or the false sense of security of Surprise (Asobi Asobase), it's completely forgetable. The ED is slighly better, but it's no Wish me Luck (Harukana Receive) or Koko Kara (Sora Yori).


The OST is also mediocre, inexistant and doesn't complement the very few interesting scenes that Goblin Slayer had. The seiyuus did a serviceable job to express the mediocrity of the series, Nao Touyama voicing the High Elf was spot on and the way she says Orcbolg is so cute and funny.


Characters (5/10):

Goblin Slayer is a determined man who only specializes on killing goblins, and he does a quite efficient job of it, however, his personality is quite twisted and ridiculous. While I'll mostly defend a person if he chooses to do a job not done by the other people, I won't with GS because he's full of vengeance, while understandable, it's a weak excuse.


The girls are the Priestess who is a very young girl who works with magic spells and healing spells, she's mostly shy and quiet and mostly goes through the motions, but there's some improvement, not too much to say. The Elf is the only acceptable character as she provides the funny moments, which somehow helped me to not getting more bored than I was, but she is literally a Shino Asada-wannabe (SAO); I won't lie if I say I didn't like when she said "Orcbolg"


The other guys are the Dwarf and the Lizard, both are quite competent when doing the quests and are very helpful of Goblin Slayer, they're not charismatic to earn some praise apart of their efficiency. The rest of the secondary characters are even worse in this point.


Enjoyment (6/10):

When I give a note below 7 in something is because there are severe deficiencies in a certain aspect of something. The enjoyment of Goblin Slayer is low if you're coming to see some dark fantasy and constant gore scenes, I for one, who is very sensible to high amounts of blood, feel very disappointed in the way this anime turn out to be.


I joked in a website that Goblin Slayer is the new Darling in the Franxx who is not Darling in the Franxx; the latter had at least some direction, high development in the characters' personalities and had the conservative flair, while the former is boring and repetitive without the hardness and crudeness of DarliFra.


A final parting message is that if Goblin Slayer comes back as the final scene suggests, I hope it's not a repetition of the direction this season had.


Final score: 6/10.

If you manage to sit through a very unsettling first episode of Goblin Slayer, you will experience a miserable fantasy adventure afterwards. Studio “White Fox” usually delivers high quality anime, as a result, I am genuinely baffled, how little enjoyment I found in this particular project. 
At least for me, manga created the impression, that Goblin Slayer is an imitation of a D&D board game, with focus on witty battle strategies as well as amusing squad chemistry in an unforgiving harsh fantasy world with lore elements sprinkled across many (missing) dialogues. Not so much fan service and gore feast. 
SCORE: Bad – 3.
STORY: Will fiton a dirty napkin.

Goblin Slayer’s overall story is quite simple, almost nonexistent – it presents more or less isolated adventures and goblin exterminations. Relentless pacing propels already shallow narrative from one goblin cave to another, ignoring world building or character interactions. Pacing and resources are mismanaged to the point, that there is a recap after only 10 episodes and it starts with a booty shot. Priorities on display. 

The only praise I can give is ep10 finale, because it was built in small steps from early on and utilizes deceitfully peaceful atmosphere presented in said episode. 


CHARACTERS: A tin can, a lizard, a dwarf & an elf walk into a cave…

Goblin Slayer, titular main character, is a walking robot, with limited vocabulary and range of emotions. The show tries to portray him as a badass goblin apocalypse; with emphasis on “tries”. He is followed by just as faceless lizard, dwarf and an elf. Young human girl with PTSD and weak bladder is the most vivid caricature in this squad. 

With the exception of a bonfire talk in ep3 and some moments in ep10, squad interactions are limited to slaying goblins. Characters cannot develop and shine in such constrained environment. In addition, the concept of a nameless world did not transfer well into anime.


ART & ANIMATION: If you do not have the budget, do not work on challenging projects.

Character designs are detailed and mostly on model; backgrounds often consist of dark caves or ruins and are interchangeable. Visuals are basic, but functional.

Action scenes are barely animated, like most of the show, with the exception of boobs. Brawls with goblins lack impact or excitement, because they often consist of static “BOOM” or “SLASH” images as well as overabundance of blood fountains in slow motion. The emphasis on witty strategies, preparation and teamplay to be victorious on the battlefield are not integral to the show. To save even more money, on every opportunity Mr. Slayer or goblins themselves are replaced with eye-catching CGI. 


SOUND: Devastating. 

OST is bland and forgettable. 

Slayer never shows his face to the audience, thus his voice actor had a difficult task to capture and express emotions to make the character appealing. This emotionless tin can performance radiates no charisma, rather reluctance. The “request” scene in ep12 was particularly underwhelming.

Lizard and mage sound interesting and project at least some personality, everyone else is unremarkable.  


Goblin Slayer the anime is a disappointment. In an unlikely case of interest, I would suggest to read the manga. If it has to be an anime with a gritty fantasy setting, goblins and a proper squad chemistry “Hai to Gensou no Grimgar” could be an alternative.

Goblin Slayer is a show the relies PURELY on shock value. The start of the show got TONS of media attention because it was a PG-rated show with non-PG attributes. The entire show itself is basically one huge hype train that leads….. I really don’t know, somewhere? There’s no real end goal besides “the extermination of all goblins” but that’s really it.
TL;DR 
It’s a HUGE hit-or-miss show, either you’re going to make it through the first episode or you’re going to drop it. However, if you make it through you’ll be rewarded with an endless cliffhanger reminiscent of shows that have a LOT more episodes.
Story7: From what I can understand you’re not getting anything groundbreaking in the story department. (However, the show is called Goblin Slayer so you WILL get goblin slaying)


Like I said before the entire show is highly dependent on shock value, something crazy happens and the show tries its best to make the viewer feel some sort of fear for the well being of all the characters… That’s it, there’s no real narrative or goal it's just random events that all relate to goblin slaying and that’s it. That’s literally the entire show, it’s not bad because they don’t expect you to know anything but people who only want stories are going to be SORELY disappointed. 


Art 7: CGI


Not nearly as bad as Berserker and has several well-animated scenes.The first episode gives a VERY bad impression on how CGI is used throughout the series, but I despise  CGI no matter where it is. Other than that, a lot of the fight scenes are badass, Goblin Slayer will just run around slicing through goblins, throw his sword, and just continue on the fight with a club like nothing happens. At these moments the show is near perfect, it’s great as long as it lasts but all good things much end and when the combat scenes end the animation quality DROPS.


Sound 9: Heavy Metal reminiscent of Doom


The opening and closing are all great, that’s enough to give it a 9 despite the rest of the track being mediocre.


Character 8: Nothing much individually but sometimes it feels like the entire cast just clicks and they seem like a genuine party.


You have your traumatized MC who does whatever it takes to kill all the (Insert random monster) he sees because they killed their family which is what we see in a lot of shows. However, something that the show tries to convey is that Goblin Slayer is not some unkillable god-like monster who could obliterate you by looking at you, in fact, he’s not strong at all he’s creative. 


You have your Priest character who owes her life to GS because he saved her in a cave, you have your childhood friend who harbors feelings for the MC, you elf girl she meets because she-- HEY WAIT A SECOND! This is a harem anime! Or it WOULD be if he was even remotely interested in anything except killing goblins. I would say it was kind of annoying but in the sea of mentally retarded main characters, this is actually a breath of fresh air.


Enjoyment 10: Maybe I’m still reminiscing about playing Doom for three hours straight every day, but when the action picks up, the show gets AMAZING. 


Overall 8: WARNING! JUST LIKE ALL SHOWS IN EXISTENCE, THIS SHOW IS NOT FOR EVERYONE! 


This show is exclusively for action fans who don’t really care about the story


I guess

This anime is very well adapted; the decision to swap the arcs makes the season flow very well and come to a solid conclusion.
While it is a relatively plain story, its simplicity could be said to be a strong point.
While some people may find the first episode a little bit hard to handle, the impact of it is necessary to show the gravitas and the motivation behind the main character. Funny enough I started Goblin Slayer with the worse impression ever and ended it thinking it was an amazing series.
Goblin Slayer is a great series under the surface. Sadly it started off horribly which must have put many people off it. 
Personally I wanted to continue the series just to see if it got better. 
Surprisingly literally after episode 1 the series got much better becoming a proper adventure anime I could enjoy. 
The characters of Goblin Slayer are quite likable and because of the unpredictability of the series I was always hoping they'd come out ok of every fight.
I quite like Goblin Slayer asits like an underdog story of a normal adventurer instead of an OP isekai protagonist that we've seen a lot of.

Please note this review is intended to be read by those that have finished watching Goblin Slayer and while care has been taken to minimize story related spoilers there may still be spoilers within character analysis. You have been warned. 
Based off a popular light novel of the same name Goblin Slayer is a action, adventure and dark fantasy anime that gives us the opportunity to see what will happen if a rookie adventurer embarking on her first ever adventure were to not just encounter the grim fatal reality that comes from being an adventurer but also realize that to be successful in this roleshe must not only dispel all of the misconceptions that she has so far believed but also learn that out on the frontier in this grim world adaptability, teamwork and a desire to learn new tactics and strategy is what would ensure that she and her comrades will be able to return to the guild after a successful mission. Though animes that make use of fantasy worlds are relatively common within the world of anime I would say that animes that make use of the dark fantasy setting as its main setting is a rare one and in fact, this one is perhaps the first example, I saw of one. This usage of a such a grim setting where every creature that the adventurers encounter can potentially cut short their careers if they underestimate them, I thought was an interesting one as it ensured that each of the fights that the adventurers encounter in the story to be that much more dangerous and brutal. 


The overall story of Goblin Slayer takes place in a rather grim fantasy world where the various races that inhabit the world that includes humans, dwarves, lizardmen, and elves live in constant fear of attacks from the many hostile races that share their world with them. These threats to their wellbeing include the infamous demon lords, ogre’s, giant rats and finally the titular villain of the series which is the goblin race. In this grim world where death can literally come from any quarter there are however many brave individuals who though coming from all walks of life and having many different kinds of motivations all have one thing in common which is a desire to explore the land and live a life that’s full of adventure as they go from place to place fulfilling quests. These people are the adventurer’s people who are not just brave enough to explore the frontier and take on difficult quests from the guild but also brave enough to face the many hostile creatures that inhabit the darkest shadows of the land. However, for every successful quest that is completed, there are also many quests that will see many a party of adventurers wiped out. 


After priestess, a rookie adventure’s party is wiped out by goblins during their attempted completion of what was supposed to be an easy mission Priestess fully expects the same fate to befall her, but she is saved by the timely intervention of a veteran adventurer who had been tracking the goblins coincidently. Despite the trauma that she had sustained the Priestess still determined to live her life as an adventurer where she can help protect the people across the land and help alleviate the sense of dread that they get from seeing the horrors that inhabit the land decides to team up with the veteran adventurer that had saved her life the Goblin slayer and having seen the threat posed by the goblins assist him in hunting down goblins across the land and stop them from committing the same actions that had so scarred the both of them. Joining them in this quest of vengeance and adventure are a host of characters that include the confident and prideful Elf archer, the kind and attentive Jou and the perceptive and wise sword maiden. 


As the priestess and her comrades embark on their adventure she will find that through the world outside of the towns may be grim and that they may face powerful enemies as long as she and the party fight creatively and learn to bond with each other and form friendships with each other no matter what quest they take and what foe they face they will succeed and be able to hand in their quest back at the guild and end each day with a victory by surviving another day in this grim and dark world. 


Priestess 


Priestess portrayed by veteran seiyuu singer Yui Ogura of Kamisama no Memochou and Vivid Strike fame is one of the main characters of the series and is the main heroine of the series. A 15-year-old girl and a rookie adventurer at the start of the series Priestess on initial appearances can be seen to be a quiet, intelligent and calm person by nature that prefers to be cautious and act only when she has gathered all necessary information. A perceptive person by nature Priestess in the beginning of the series as a result of her new role was shown to be someone that was easily scared and when paired with her quiet nature made it easy for others to intimidate her which is shown well in the first interactions with her first party. While Priestess was shown to be a knowledgeable person, she often displayed hesitation in providing that knowledge to others as a result of her desire to not cause others too much bother and hinder the party’s progress a fact that unfortunately played a role in causing the destruction of the first party that she was part of. 


After Priestess was saved by the Goblin slayer her personality gradually starts to change as she overcomes the shock and trauma that befell her in the aftermath of her first battle. While still retaining her cautious nature Priestess gradually starts to overcome her quiet and timid nature and becomes more willing to speak up and present her own opinions and feelings to others. At the same time Priestess also begins to show the friendly and caring side to her personality that she had kept hidden previously taking great care to try and forge bonds and friendships with both the Goblin Slayer and later the other members of the party in an effort to both know them on a personal level and at the same time get to know how their weaponry and skills can be best used in battle. One of the notable examples of this change within her was Priestess’s constant attempts to try and teach the Goblin Slayer how basic human interactions work which while amusing was proof of the determined attempts of priestess to not let what happened to her first party happen a second time. While still indecisive at times as the series goes on and the party encounters and fights many fearsome foes Priestess gradually becomes braver and more determined to both protect her new comrades and to ensure that they will be able to complete each of their assigned quests and return home safely after each adventure. While seen in the beginning to be somewhat intimidated by the Goblin slayer as the series goes on it can be seen that the Priestess forms a strong emotional bond with him that can be said to be the very foundation of her being and is something that is able to give her the motivation that she needs to fight alongside him on the frontlines. However, it can be said that this is a double-edged sword of sorts as seeing him get hurt or perceiving that he will leave her will have the opposite effect of causing her to worry more about him. As a character, I felt that Priestess was one that was both well designed and developed. While the trauma that she suffered from seeing her first party get wiped out by goblins was no doubt traumatic I felt that her overcoming of that sad event by using her newly developed bond with the Goblin slayer as a foundation from which she can change herself was something that I thought was done well. Seeing the priestess evolve from a quiet and indecisive person to one that was not just brave but also willing to state her own views freely while adapting to the changing nature of the frontlines was a change that I really enjoyed seeing. One of the things that I found to be most endearing about the character of Priestess was her attempts to change the Goblin Slayers personality a fact that while certainly amusing also served well to show the level of trust that she has developed in him and at the same time visible proof of the growing affection that she has for him. 


Goblin Slayer 


Goblin Slayer portrayed by veteran voice actor Yuuichirou Umehara of Amanchu and Darling in the Franxx fame is one of the main characters of the series and is the main protagonist of the series. A veteran adventurer of the guild with the rank of a silver ranked adventurer Goblin Slayer at the beginning of the series was seen to be a quiet, gruff but brave person who rather than embark on adventures with either a partner or a party instead strives to take on missions’ solo. While often seen as difficult to approach by many which isn’t helped by the fact that Goblin Slayer tries hard to avoid interacting with others much it can be seen that beneath this Goblin Slayer can be surprisingly kind to others and display a certain level of intelligence that can surprise many. Though seen as a rather direct person by nature it can also be seen that Goblin Slayer is also a responsible and dutiful person who always tries his hardest to complete the quests that were assigned to him. Due in part to his desire to remain isolated from others in the beginning of the series Goblin Slayer was noted to not be very good at working with others and while he can give them simple orders his desire to not let strong emotions cloud his judgment made it hard for him to work with the Priestess at first. This desire to not let emotions cloud his judgment is shown well in the realist attitude that he takes when presented with grim reports for he always expects the worst when the facts are made known to him. However while quiet and preferring to keep his own counsel, in the beginning, it can be seen that Goblin Slayer while possessing no talent for inspirational speeches and the like is a surprisingly attentive listener which when combined by his honest and direct nature makes him very good at providing advice to others. 


As the series goes on however and as Goblin Slayer not just encounters but also befriends and teams up with other adventurers his personality gradually starts to change. As a result of the long periods of time that he spent on solo missions, Goblin Slayer was noted early on to have learned many unique knowledge and tactics that proved to be just as effective when used by a party as it was by himself. While Goblin Slayers nature, in the beginning, worked against him this gradually began to change as he began to fight alongside the others and in the process learn both the value of teamwork but also of the value of having someone that you trust watching your back a feeling that until now was utterly alien to him. As a result, while still retaining his quiet nature Goblin Slayer also began to show more care and consideration towards the well being of his allies and gradually beginning to open his heart to them. This is best shown in his willingness to not just listen to their own thoughts and advice on the various situations that the party encounters in the field but also in his willingness to not just trust them to guard his back but also in running missions independent of him. While mainly seen as a fighter within the series it can be seen rather surprisingly that Goblin Slayer can also be a surprisingly capable commander as well that when used in combination with the increased bond and trust that has been formed between the members of the party and his extensive knowledge of combat that he gained from years of solo adventuring can pull of some impressively creative tactics that serve well to even out the odds that are all too often arrayed against them. This is shown well in the myriad number of fights and traps that the party manages to overcome over the course of the series. The character of the Goblin Slayer I felt was an interesting character that though shaped by the tragic circumstance of his childhood trauma he not only endured but took on a role where he can exact his revenge on the race that had caused him so much pain. The development of Goblin Slayer from someone that preferred to stay apart from others and wage a solo struggle against the goblins to someone who not just found the warmth and friendship that was unique to parties but also the advantages that it can bring to him whether on a professional level or a personal level was a change that I really enjoyed seeing within him. Indeed one event that I felt showed this development of this well enough was the event in which Goblin Slayer had food with not just the members of his party but also with the friends that have proved dear to him in life. 


High Elf Archer 


High Elf archer portrayed by veteran seiyuu singer Nao Touyama of Beatless and Asterisk Wars fame is one of the main supporting characters of the series and is one of Goblin Slayers fellow party members within the series. A member of the long-lived elf race High Elf archer at the beginning of the series was seen to be a confident and haughty person by nature that as a result had great difficulty in asking others for help despite the initial reason for her and her parties’ reason for seeking out the Goblin Slayer. As a result of this nature, High Elf archer was seen to be someone that looked down on others and was someone that defended herself fiercely from the comments made by others in response by having a retort ready at all times. However, despite her self-confidence and haughty nature High Elf archer was also shown to display a playful and teasing nature at times willing to make jokes at odd moments at times that serve well to alleviate some of the tension that came about from her first interactions with Goblin Slayer and company. Despite the long years that Elf’s are known to live for it can be seen that High Elf archer is someone that lacks any real experience both in terms of being an adventurer and also in dealing with races other than her fellows. As a result of this inexperience, she can be seen to be curious towards the nature of the world around her which is shown well in how she reacts when she encounters situations that she has yet to encounter in her life. At the same time, however, she was also seen to be ignorant of the basic tactics that adventures should be using when in the field such as using monster blood to help mask their scent skills that would have been second nature to adventurers. Indeed, while lacking any sort of experience as an adventurer it can be seen that High Elf archer has a rather lofty idea of the adventures that adventurers actually go on when they depart for quests which from her impression seems to be one that’s filled with fun and laughter rather than the grim and brutal battles that are instead the norm of such lives. Despite her prideful and confident nature however High Elf archer is shown to be a formidable combatant being not just a capable archer but also an effective tracker as well. Unlike her default personality in combat, she was shown to be calm, logical and made great use of her pride as a source of strength a contrast that I felt showed that despite her inexperience as both an adventurer and a person she was willing to work hard to learn and improve herself. 


As the series goes on however and as High Elf archer gets to understand the kind of life that adventures actually lead as well as learn to appreciate the types of bonds and teamwork that can come from working effectively with others her personality starts to gradually change. At the beginning of the series, High Elf archer was noted to not have a very good relationship with Goblin slayer due mostly to the fact that he wore low-grade gear and was seemingly focused on fighting goblins which she regarded as low tier foes. However, as the series went on and she got to see the true reality of the threat that was posed by the goblins and the solo war that Goblin Slayer had been waging against them this sense of dislike eventually evolved to that of respect and eventually trust. This is shown well in the fact that she was willing to let him dictate the kind of tactics and strategy that would be used in the many battles that the party faces in their journey. While still possessing the strong pride that defines her character as she learns more about the members of the party and how things work in this world High Elf archer’s attitude gradually matures becoming friendlier, kinder and more considerate of the feeling of others especially to those that has earned her trust. While no longer letting pride dictate her actions it can be seen that she doesn’t discard it entirely as she uses it instead as a source of motivation that she uses to interact better with her party members and improve not just the relationship that she has with them but also their effectiveness as a party as well. Perhaps the greatest change that came from this change in her character was the kind of interactions that she has with Goblin Slayer as in addition to being kinder to him she also began to show a softer side to him as well that showed not just consideration but also a playful and teasing nature as she tried to learn about him a change that I found refreshing. 


Guild Girl 


Guild girl portrayed by veteran seiyuu singer Maaya Uchida of Charlotte and Killing Bites fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is one of Goblin Slayer’s allies within the series. A member of the adventures guild that works as one of their receptionists Guild girl on initial appearances is seen to be a kind, caring and polite person by nature that tries hard to present a friendly face to the many adventurers that are based within the town. While a kind person by nature Guild Girl is also shown to be an attentive and helpful person and tries her best to help the adventurers that use the guild as their base. While seen as professional and dutiful to her role as the public face of the guild it can be seen that beneath her smile Guild girl is someone that can be seen to be empathic to both the grief that adventurers may encounter when out on the field as well as feelings that the victims of the crimes that are dealt against them by the creatures of darkness. As a result of this unique ability to understand the types of feelings that are carried by others that they try to hide beneath the surface she unlike the rest of the guild can be seen to display more sense of caution in her dealings with the adventurers that she manages and while knowing that she may be sending them to their deaths for every quest that she dispatches them on she at least tries to provide them with the best advice and intel that she can find before doing so. This sense of trying to ensure that her charges not just have a chance of surviving their first forays into the cruel world into which they live despite the fact that she was supposed to maintain a professional relationship between them I felt was a trait that suited her personality pretty well as it highlighted the fact that while she knew how grim the world outside was in her own way she was also trying to ensure that the light that is the adventurers will have a higher chance of surviving their missions and thus aid in making the world a better place. 


One of the more curious aspects of Guild girl’s character is arguably the relationship that exists between her and the Goblin Slayer. Unlike the rest of the adventurer’s guild who show nothing but disdain for him, it can be seen that contrary to the others Guild girl instead is someone that treats him with both kindness and care and indeed is shown to have a lot of respect for him that seems genuine. From looking at the empathic nature that serves as the Guild girls most prominent trait it can be seen that this sense of respect is borne out of the gratitude that she feels for him taking on quests that will not just protect the people from threats that most other adventurers would not handle but at the same time help ensure that rookie adventurers would not meet a grim fate when facing the goblins that are more cunning and powerful than others give them credit for. While showing him genuine respect and treating him as a valued comrade it can be seen that Guild girls’ feelings towards the Goblin Slayer is above that of a professional level and indeed is more akin to that of a friend than anything. This is shown in the display of various strong feelings that she shows when she sees him return whether its displays of joy when she sees him return unharmed and the display of dismay when she sees and hears that he ‘s been injured. This is reinforced by the fact that she’s willing to use her authority to force him to take more care in his quests by using the threat of not giving him quests to intimidate him which while amusing perhaps hints that she desires something more from him. 


Sword Maiden 


Sword Maiden portrayed by veteran seiyuu Aya Endou of Accel World and Comic Girls fame is one of the main support characters of the series and is one of Goblin Slayers main allies within the series. A former gold ranked adventurer and presently the Archbishop of the church of water city Sword Maiden on initial appearances is seen to be a kind, considerate and caring person by nature whose persona as presented to the world is seen by many to be the ideal image of what a respected hero should be like. A calm and composed person by nature Sword Maiden despite her blindness is shown to be both perceptive and wise able to offer surprisingly wise advice to the people that she encounters as part of her duties. However, despite this nature of hers, it can be seen that Sword Maiden can also display a certain level of cunning within her that she uses to create plans when discretion is needed something that I felt was quite surprising given her calling. 


Despite her calm and composed nature however, it can be seen Sword Maiden can also be seen to have a more innocent side to her personality as she can also be playful and teasing to others when needed which is shown well in the aftermath of the miracle that she performed on Goblin Slayer that ended up saving his life. As a result of being seen as one of the most powerful adventurers that the land has ever produced its perhaps unsurprising that even as a member of the church that Sword-Maiden is held in high regard by people across the land. As a result of this Sword Maiden can be seen to need to project to others a certain level of calmness and a level of mental strength that someone of her skill and rank would be expected to have. However, while certainly appearing to be mentally strong on the surface beneath this it can be seen that Sword Maiden’s mental state is actually quite fragile. As a result of both her role as an archbishop of the church and her status as a former high ranked adventurer Sword Maiden can be seen to be under a lot of pressure that had the side effect of preventing her from telling others of both her inner thoughts as well as the secret fears that she has inside her. Due to this despite appearing to have everything that most people would want be it rank or power it can be seen that she’s also somewhat lonely as well. However, after meeting Goblin Slayer this changed for while Goblin slayer was not the best of conversationalist’s he at least understood the pain that she had been hiding within her as a result of their shared experiences and due to his nature can be said to be the person that she had so desired to meet for a long time. While this meeting did not affect Sword Maiden’s surface personality much the effects that it had on her mental state however was significant as for the first time, she was able to tell others the pain and fear that she had been hiding within her and in the process managing to find someone that she can rely on. The character of Sword Maiden I felt was an interesting one and while she was only featured within the series for a short time the effect that she had on the cast was significant. The insight into Sword Maiden’s mental state I felt was an interesting one and while seeing her gradually come to grips with her inner struggles by revealing them to the Goblin slayer managed to add more depth to her character I also felt that this aspect also allowed us to understand that in addition to physical pain that adventures can suffer they can also suffer mental trauma that they can be secretly struggling with. 


AMV 


In terms of animations, I thought that the series animation was pretty well done and that it did a great job of showing the kinds of terrain types and locations that can exist in a world that makes use of the dark fantasy setting and was noted to have quite the variety of locations. The contrast between these locations from the various ruins and caves that the party visit to the farm and the town that houses the guild I felt took great advantage of this fact.  The character designs of the series whether in terms of character designs for the main characters and their allies I thought were pretty done with each character’s outfits and weapons doing a good job of showing the kind of roles that they have both in combat and as adventurers. The combat animation within the series I felt was pretty smooth and did a great job of showing the brutal and gritty nature of the fights that can take place between adventurers and monsters. This was helped greatly by the well designed and developed fights that the cast find themselves in as they go about their adventures. Noteworthy ones that I particularly enjoyed was the fight against the ogre and the siege in the sewers that pitted the party against a sustained attack by a large goblin host that was led by a goblin champion. The enemy designs I felt was also something that was impressive and while individual lower ranked goblins didn’t have many variations, I felt that the design for the larger and more intelligent goblins like the goblin champion, pirate goblin and the design for the ogre were definitely on point as they showed just how powerful and monstrous the creatures of darkness can be. 


Music wise the series made use of one opening and ending theme which was Rightfully that was performed by Mili and Gin No Kisei that was performed by Soraru. Both of these songs I felt contrasted well with each other with the opening being hauntingly beautiful and the ending being dramatic. The series OST I felt was a solid one and did well to complement the various kinds of situations that the party encounters when they are out fulfilling missions. In terms of voice acting, I felt that the series voice cast all did an excellent job at portraying their assigned characters whether main ones or support ones. In particular, I feel that Yui Ogura, Yuuichirou Umehara, Nao Touyama, Maaya Uchida and Aya Endou deserve special praise as I felt that they managed to an excellent job in portraying the characters of Priestess, Goblin Slayer, High Elf archer, Guild girl and Sword Maiden respectively. In addition, while I didn’t cover them within the review, I also felt that Yuka Iguchi, Tomokazu Sugita and Yuuichi Nakamura who portrayed the characters of Musume, lizard priest and the dwarf shaman all did an excellent job in portraying their assigned characters. 


Overall conclusion 


Overall Goblin Slayer was an anime that I really enjoyed with its main strengths, in my opinion, being its interesting premise, a unique setting that’s seldom seen in anime, strong and well-developed characters, well designed and developed fights that showed the harsh realities of life as an adventurer and strong voice acting from a capable voice cast. 


The series overall premise which is the depiction of the kind of challenges and risks that people who chose to become adventurers can be expected to encounter as they take up that role and make the job of being an adventurer the path that they will follow until death claims them is without a doubt one of the main highlights of this series. While the premise is certainly a dark one and within some circles a deeply controversial one due to the myriad number of fates that can befell such people I felt that the premise that combined the enthusiasm and hopes that rookie adventurers have for having taken up a job that can earn them great riches with the harsh realities of the types of fearsome creatures that they have to face on a daily basis when out on quests contrasted well with each other.  However while certainly grim this premise also did well in highlighting the fact that only those who are willing to endure and learn to overcome their fear of the unknown and learn to hone the skills that are unique to their jobs and work as part of a team can hope to survive and earn the riches and titles that comes from being able to both take on and vanquish the most dangerous of monsters. 


The overall story of the series I felt made great use of this grim premise by showing not just how a rookie adventurer who was saved from certain death was to not just grow in strength as both a person and an adventurer but in the process learn that while the world around them might be a grim one and that death may await them behind every corner as long as they were able to stay motivated, keep their fear in check, learn to bond with and develop friendships with another and more importantly learn to place your trust in one another then the chances of an adventurer and his party not just surviving the missions and adventures that they embark on but also learn to work as a well-oiled party will become exponentially higher. Seeing both the Goblin Slayer and the priestess gradually bond with their fellow party members and learn to trust each other as they embark on multiple hard missions that will pit them against countless powerful creatures of darkness and see the effects that this has on the teamwork of the party while doing well in showing the growth of each member also proved that with trust, friendship and creative use of strategy no matter how grim the situation is they can fight and win against any threat their comes their way. This act of seeing the party members not just overcome their initial mistrust but also learn to trust and fight together and, in the process, discovering the hidden strength that comes from being with your comrades was something that I really enjoyed seeing within the series. 


Overall Goblin Slayer was an anime that while darker and grittier than I expected it to be was still one that I really enjoyed as it showed that no matter how grim a world is and how much the odds are stacked against you as long as you have friends and comrades that you can place your trust in to not just watch your back but also fight alongside you a party no matter how inexperienced they are can learn to not just excel in their roles as adventurers but also stand as a bulwark that protects the people that are dear to them from the predations of the creatures of darkness. As a final score, I would say that Goblin Slayer easily deserves a final score of 8/10.

Goblin Slayer, one of the most controversial animes of not just the season but of the year. But does it deserve all the flak it gets? I will say this right here that the amount of Goblin rape mentioned and used is unnecessary, I can understand mentioning it once or twice in the middle of the show would be acceptable but to start the first episode with what is basically a rape scene is confusing to the audience. This show is like a tale of two tapes. The side of brutal goblin slaying and the threats they pose, and the lightheartedness of a broken manas his friends try to fix him. Overall Goblin Slayer is a show that can be enjoyed by a mass audience but is scrutinized for its few mistakes that carry heavy burden. 


Animation (9/10): I don't have much to say here, I rather like Goblin Slayer’s animation. I dock a point for its sometimes shotty CGI but over then that I enjoy it. Characters are given lifelike faces and bodies and even the fantasy beasts are shown in a way that gives them a real look. And when the mood changes to a more comedic effect the faces are used to perfection. Animation is not something that takes away from the show. 


Music/Voice Acting (7-8/10): I am kinda mixed here, the music is okay but it doesn't add anything to the show. But if it doesn't add or take away then I guess it's more of a neutral factor. Voice acting wise is more annoying. I rather like the dub because it seems to give Goblin Slayer more emotion than his more deadpan Japanese counterpart. However, and yes I know it's not the shows fault, its use of lesser known voice actors in the dub takes away the potential it could of had. In both cases the voice acting does enough to not take away from the show but doesnt give it that memorable feel. 


Characters (8/10): They may not be the most original characters but I enjoy them. The stereotypical ness of them I think adds to the show and allows them to mesh well. Goblin slayer is only abnormal as he would often be the mindless brute but instead is the strategic brute. Then the mix of Elf, Dwarf, Lizardman and Priestess blend well enough to give it a ragtag family feel. It could be personally preference but I find Elf Ranger the best as she gives a comedic and more realistic response to Goblin Slayer’s actions, while the rest, with some exceptions for Priestess, more or less go along with his plans. While most won't be life changing favorite characters, unless you like huge boobs or stubborn flat girls, the characters blend well together. 


Plot (6/10): Goblin Slayer’s plot is a sticky situation. While not so much overarching, besides maybe changing Goblin Slayer, the 2-3 episode plots are rather interesting and often provide new world and character development. Even the subplot about the hero killing the demon world adds to the story without taking it off its course to much. But to be really critical the amount of rape in this takes away a good chunk of points. Like I said before a few mentions to set the threat would of been fine, but its like every other episode they want to mention or show that Goblins are horny little things. It honestly gets annoying and gross, to the shows credit after the first episode it more mentions then shows it happening, with a couple exceptions, which at least doesn't have its viewers watching Goblin rape for a quarter of the episode. 


Enjoyment: (8.5/10): Minus Goblin rape scenes I loved watching this show. The lighthearted comedic moments were enough to make me laugh while the brutal actions scenes filled a excellent mix of brutal violence and strategy. If it wasn't for the holidays I would have watched the whole series in the 4-5 hours it would take, I really can't think of much more to say here besides don’t let the negative opinions of this show stop you from seeing it for yourself. 


Overall (8/10): Goblin Slayer deserves a lot more praise then it gets. Looking at it from a far it might seem like a stupid show but it is the opposite. Goblin Slayer won't teach you some important lesson or make you cry. But it will make a fun watch that will fill a adrenaline and comedic need. This show will stick in my memory and I only hope it gets more seasons so I can enjoy the glory that is Goblin Slayer. Hopefully with a lot less Goblin Rape.

I watched the first five episodes like a while ago and stopped watching it because, even if this show is not entirely terrible, there is way better shows out there that deserves my attention. Now with the rest...

Let's talk about these ''characters''

Oh boy...

This whole anime feels like the studio made an animation over some edgy 14 years old fanfiction written in one night. It doesn't seem to get better after the fifth episode anyway so I don't think I'll be finishing it anytime soon.

I love playing Role Playing Games especially if the RPG set in medieval age with dungeon crawling and flying wild dragons everywhere. Not just that, I am quite familiar with the game of Dungeons and Dragons which is a tabletop version of action-fantasy RPG. For me, Goblin Slayer is a re-imagination of Dungeons and Dragons with a very cruel Dungeon Master who loves to torture the players with little things that often overlooked by everyone. But before we started to get into the review, let's begin with my opinion about controversy that has been lingering around this anime from the very first episode.
The first episodeof Goblin Slayer shown a major disturbing scene of rape and Crunchyroll carelessly put it on stream without any warning, starting the controversy we know today. Since the setting of fantasy with goblins and creatures is already staple with our regular Isekai anime (even when this anime is nowhere near Isekai), people thought at first that this anime would not be that dark. So, that was where exactly the controversy begin. But, what about my opinion? While many people said it was far too edgy for an anime set in fantasy world, I think the disturbing scene is very important for Goblin Slayer's cruel world building. It is very clear that the writer wanted us to know how fearsome little goblins are, especially in huge groups and in their own nest. But the most important is they want to set a lore that there's no female goblin in this world of Goblin Slayer thus making a purpose for the goblin to attack, raze, and kidnap women and children. So, yeah. While I am still a bit disturbed, I still think the disturbing scene is important point for this series to go on.


Now, with that settled, let's talk about the story and characters. As the title suggest, Goblin Slayer revolved around the not-so-adventure of a man who always takes goblin slaying quests. His backstory is quite simple and yet, it is fitting for a story took place in fantasy world like this. The story of wanderlust caused by loss of the loved ones just like a character creation in an RPG. After all, the characters in this anime felt like a personification of Dungeons and Dragons character sheet. Not just that, Goblin Slayer is a man of few words, making him a more fitting description of RPG main protagonist. I love how he eventually ended up in a party consisted of a fairly new adventurer Priestess, a drunken Dwarf Shaman, a cocky High Elf Archer, and a cheese loving Lizard Priest. The party is drawn to him by his deed of slaying goblins, not by his persuasion as he does not talk much (to the point he received a protest from Priestess). This is extended to other people like the Sword Maiden and other adventurers in the guild.


Oh yeah, I really love how they kept the characters unnamed and how they kept it that way throughout the series. It made this feeling of anyone could step into those characters shoes. It could be me, it could be you, and it could be anyone.


My major problem in this anime probably caused by its CGI. I know very well that Goblin Slayer's character design is very much hard to redraw yet very cool and intimidating. I praise anyone who design the characters for those. But it seems the difficulties in redrawing Orcbolg makes the studio decided to utilize CGI for Goblin Slayer's movement. While good CGI models and animations could lead into beautiful animation and direction, the CGI model of Goblin Slayer felt weird as the movements of the model are far too awkward and unnatural. Not just that, the inconsistent changing between 2D and 3D makes me want to say "Makeup your mind already!" I just really hope they are going to makeup their mind in the continuation of this series.


Then, let's continue to the soundtrack. While not too remarkable or outstanding, the rocking metal soundtracks in Goblin Slayer surprisingly fit the theme very well. It made my blood boils as The Beard Cutter trying to slash here and there. Simply, the soundtracks amplified Goblin Slayer's hatred towards the goblins very well, reaching the heart of the audience. The opening sequence itself felt very fitting to the dark theme of Goblin Slayer and it accompanied by many references of Dungeons and Dragons in the animation sequence and in the song lyrics as well. Talk about the opening, I think you should check out the music video. I love the performance of that performer who tries to convey a man who literally lost his humanity. So, check them out!


Overall, a continuation of this series is probably a must do since there are still some things that we want to see like the adventure Orcbolg wanted and promised by him to the High Elf Archer. If the animators decided to fix the CGI problem whether making the CGI movements better or maybe getting rid of it, the second season probably could outmatched the first one. And so, I will look forward for the continuation!
