Summary: Goblin Slayer will not go down as the most memorable anime of the year, or even the season. It is, by almost all means, average at best. This being said, watch it if you want a "turn your brain off and enjoy" type of show! I enjoyed this show thoroughly, and despite its mediocrity, found it one of the easier shows to binge that I've watched in quite some time. 
WARNING: This one is gorier and more graphic than your typical anime, especially in the first episode. 
Story: 6/10
This story is nothing more than typical. The setting is ripped straight from Dungeons and Dragons,as are the characters. Therefore, nothing particularly crazy ever happens, and the plot is very easy to predict. In fact, the title gives the plot away! This anime was not really trying to say much, which is strangely refreshing. Not having to deal with any speculation about the hidden meanings of the show can be nice from time to time, after all.


Art: 6/10

"Average" is a proper term to describe the show's visuals. Half of the time, Goblin Slayer is animated with noticeable CG, and the supporting cast looks very faithful to the story's source material. Meaning, nothing new or groundbreaking came in the visual department, besides Goblin Slayer's signature glowing red eye in battle scenes. However, the show does a commendable job at animating crowds, and doesn't often resort to CG animation in giant hordes of Goblins or armies of adventurers.


Sound: 7/10

Music and voice acting are both pseudo-strong points of Goblin Slayer, with memorable opening/ending songs adding an especially fun aspect to episodes. In addition, the banter between characters was never dull, and always kept me engaged when the gore was toned down. They didn't do anything amazing, however, this story and the characters didn't really need them to. Finally, OST tracks were used appropriately for raising and lowering the tension of scenes.


Character: 6/10

Let me start off by reiterating: the setting is literally Dungeons and Dragons, so the characters did not deviate from that at all. They do not even have individual names. Development was very subtle, and essentially non-existent outside of Goblin Slayer and Priest. The supporting characters themselves were very cut-and-paste in essentially every fashion. The female characters, especially, seemed to be part of a developing "harem" for Goblin Slayer (though he would not be interested in that notion in the slightest.) Though, Goblin Slayer did get a fair amount of characterization, when all was said and done. By the end, his tunnel vision for Goblin-slaying seems to have diminished, and had become much more trusting/willing to rely on others. He still retained his stoic, dull demeanor that he was known for, and his vocabulary still seemed as limited as ever, but it is clear that he is not stagnant.


Enjoyment: 9/10

Oh, man. This show was enjoyable as ever for me. This may be due to one simple fact: the show knows exactly what it is. It almost seems to accept its own mediocrity, and runs with it anyway. It was not trying to have the plot of Overlord, the Comedy of Konosuba, or the Action of Berserk (okay, maybe that one's debatable...), but instead it feels comfortable in its own stereotypical, worn-out narrative. I, personally, found it very charming in this instance, because so many recent shows tend to attempt to force some kind of differentiating factor into itself, with variable results. The action, while not particularly great, was fun, the banter made the bland characters entertaining, and the rudimentary plot progressed naturally. 


Overall: 8/10

Despite so many factors being average, the charm of this show made it enjoyable enough to be rated an 8/10, in my eyes. Once in a while, it's nice to be able to throw things like character motivations, plot analysis, and high expectations out the window and just enjoy what's in front of you. That's what this show was for me: a cathartic break from the somewhat-tedious work of analyzing character-heavy or plot-heavy shows. Should your expectations be high watching this show? Absolutely not. Does this show do anything noteworthy? Hardly. But, is it enjoyable? Absolutely. Throwing out any sort of critical eyes, and instead replacing them with those of a none-the-wiser fan can often do good for the mind, and this show is a perfect opportunity to do that. Watch if you don't mind the gore and graphic content!

Goblin Slayer review:
=Contains minor spoilers=
Please note that I have not yet read the manga/LN, so this is based purely on the anime.
So lets start with the positives!
I really like the aspect of the goblins raping women as weird as it sounds. Hear me out, there's a plothole in most fantasy shows/games to do with goblins. We usually only see male goblins - so how do they reproduce? It's perfectly explained in Goblin Slayer - goblins rape women to reproduce. This also makes them seem more vile and gives another reason to kill them. 
I didn't think the show 'crossed the line' as some people havesaid online. Yes, it does have gore, rape and a dark story overall. But none of this is new. Devilman (the original and Crybaby) had gore, sex and a dark story to tell. But enough of that.


I absolutely love the soundtrack! OST is something that I find incredibly important as it really helps set the mood for the show. I can't stop listening to the opening as well.


This show is really based off DnD. Its basically a Dungeons and Dragons campaign, which I LOVE. 


At first, I REALLY didn't like Goblin Slayer (the character lol.). He just seemed to be a stereotypical emotionless character and I found it confusing as to why he only kills goblins. Now I'm not going to spoil anything, but it is explained, and I actually ended up liking GS as the show went on.


The other characters are pretty cool as well, but I don't really have a lot to say about them. 


The animation didn't really stick out to me and just wasn't that great in my opinion. Plus, GS was 3D animated I believe, which I didn't rally like. The setting was quite pretty, though and the character designs definitely stick out to me. I quite liked the art style as well. So overall, the art was pretty good, the animation isn't great.


So what about the negatives?

It kinda bugged me that none of the characters have actual names. Makes them less memorable in my opinion. 


Like I said, the animation wasn't that great and some of it was 3D animated, which I just didn't like.


I found the recap episode really boring, so I kinda just skipped that.


Those are the only real negatives that I can think of. 


You can call this show edgy (it really is) and that it crossed the line (it didn't) but I will defend this show.


If you're into DnD, dark fantasies and don't mind gore or rape, this is the show for you. However, if you dont like any of these things, it's probably not your thing. 


Overall, I personally LOVED the show and I'm hyped for season 2!!!!!

Goblin Slayer is basically a D&D session with an edgy dm and players with a very one-track mind. It still works out better than most of my D&D sessions though.
Story 6/10
The story is okay, but kind of bland. Most of the arcs boil down to the same story beats with the same conclusion. Although the goblin slayer could easily get stale the show prevents this by throwing in some tactics and fight scenes. Especially the final fights of the arcs are fun. The series isn’t just about slaying goblins all the time and contains some good downtime in between the confrontations which adds some flavourto the series. The show is kind of light on comedy, but the times it does come up it doesn’t overstay its welcome and in general the show sticks to the darker tone it establishes in the very first episode. The story does have problems with plot armour though, after a while it becomes clear that nothing lasting will ever happen to the main characters. The ending of the season was chosen well and the season ended on a high note.


Art 6/10

Goblin Slayer looks fine, but nothing really stands out. Character designs are alright and some characters are memorable. The goblins could have used some diversity among themselves as they all look pretty much the same (champions and lord excluded). The animation is okay, but nothing to write home about and some bad CGI pops up from time to time. In some scenes the animation can feel a bit static. Although the fights are fun from a story perspective they clearly lack in choreography, considering the nature of the series this is quite bad.


Sound 5/10

The sound design is completely average with some cases where the sound effects stick out a bit as well as music that sometimes overpowers the scenes in which it plays.


Character 4/10

The characters in this show are about as one dimensional as can be, character development is about non-existent with only some development from Goblin Slayer himself. Most of the main cast gets about as much development as the side characters that only show up in a few scenes. These side characters have an absolute bare minimum of personality and are all pretty much interchangeable.


Enjoyment 7/10

With all that being said, the show is still very much enjoyable despite all the flaws. The simplicity of the characters and the plot make it very easy to follow along after a long day without worrying too much about thinking.


Overall 6/10

Doom Guy would be proud.
The dark knight of the fantasy world, Goblin Slayer. Or, more accurately, "GO-bo-LEAN SLEIGH-er-san". His sword strikes down the evil midget spawns of satan, in order to protect the poor innocent villagers from their terror. Neither fame nor fortune, does he receive. Yet, he pushes on.
If you're easily disturbed by graphic content, then look someplace else. However, if your Testosterone levels are over 9000, and you need some dark fantasy to fill in the void Berserk left in you, then don't waste another second of your time, and start watching this anime.
*Non-Spoiler Review*
The story is about Goblin Slayer going out to*spoiler alert* slay some goblins. I'm sorry for dropping that bomb right after saying that this was a non-spoiler review, but it had to be done. While there doesn't seem to be anything exciting about watching a guy grind exp by slaying some low level mobs, the author manages to create situations which are engaging and at times thrilling to experience. In short, he was able to make monsters, monstrous again.


The art was fairly standard. It does have a nice touch to it at times, but it also suffers from the use of CG during many moments in the anime. However, there are a few times where the CG actually enhances the watching experience. After completing this anime, I don't have much of a problem with it, so I don't think you would either.


One of the rare English OP's used in anime. It might not seem like much at first, but once you listen to it a few times, you'll find it to be quite catchy. Plus, the metal OST used for Goblin Slayer is badass. Nothing really memorable in the OST, but it certainly gives you the hype you would expect from a show like this.


"Soka". Pretty much the only thing Goblin Slayer says, and that's all he needs to say. The man himself isn't a very interesting character, but why he is the way that he is, is explained in the story. The supporting cast are all very unique, and they feel tangible within the fantasy world that they reside in. Everyone has their own importance to the story, and in developing Goblin Slayer's character.


Watching this man cut down the little fiends is one of the most entertaining things I've watched this season. He's not some hero with op stats, and his fighting style matches with that limitation, resulting in some very creative ways of killing goblins. It's just entertaining, for all the right reasons.


It's certainly not for everyone, but it's definitely a must-watch for any dark fantasy fans out there.


Thank you for reading this review!

As a fantasy anime, I found Goblin Slayer to be rather entertaining. The main character seemed like he'd be bland, but turned out to be mildly charming in his single-mindedness, which also brought some humor to the otherwise fairly serious anime.
Some people out there seem to think it was edgy, but I don't really see it. As far as the big controversy in the first episode, I've seen worse scenes in critically acclaimed independent films. The scene itself was only a few seconds long and didn't really show anything, so don't let the whiners fool you.
Overall, the quality of the anime was fairly even acrossthe board. Story, art, sound, etc, were fairly solid. Don't expect a deep, engaging story, but there was enough to be entertaining.The sound and art were on par with the rest as well. \n\n
Looks like they tease a new season at the end. I for one look forward to seeing what Goblin Slayer does next.

Unfortunately, we have reached a status concerning Goblin Slayer where any discussion of its merits and shortcomings are trimmed out under the guise of the rambunctious controversy that befell its debut. Let me clear the air for that: anything is fair game for criticism regardless of whether or not it is controversial for any degree of reason. So I cannot sit here and understand why someone who would want to argue on a narrative’s decisions would resort to facetiously equating criticism with mere self-absorbed needs for attention and a sheep mentality. The only other more major example I can think of is Fallout 76. Peoplealready having difficulties debating the pros and cons when any word is contorted depending on whether or not the controversial nature of it makes one’s opinion differ from the other. Nothing is sacred; discuss in good faith.


Everything about Goblin Slayer is artificial and shallow. The aesthetics of the animation and artwork are rendered in service to the grimdark nature of its thematic structure and plot, which in turn are in service to enhance the weekly experience of watching OCD-levels of focus on one man hellbent on killing as many goblins in the world that is humanly possible and then some. The worst part of is that anyone believes he is anything more than empty caricature of a character. He is a gimmick, meant to produce memes and create a repetitive cycle of marketing by the sheer fact that people joke about how obsessed he is with killing goblins and then when his motivations are revealed, they fall flat on their face because it is evident how much lack of depth the program actually has. Goblins did bad things, as they always do. There’s nothing more to it than that, it is forgotten about and not explored with any more meaningful depth.


What is the show trying to do here? Is it a character study in Goblin Slayer? Is it a narrative about a fantasy world inhabited by terrible, abominable creatures? This show has absolutely no sense of direction. Tell me where the direction is. No one in the cast of characters offers any meaningful contribution besides play a role in Goblin Slayer’s MMO comradery. I figure that is enough for most anime fans, considering the plethora of otaku programs that are available. 


First, let us analyze the perspective that it is a character study of Goblin Slayer. We begin the debut episode with a novice group of nobodies. Anyone can understand the purpose they serve by the episode’s end – there’s no shame in calling them plot devices because while those concerns are valid (and will be later expanded on briefly), sometimes they are necessary and the ends justify the means in this case. The introduction to the series is world-building while the star is at the same time one lone individual. Nothing we are specially a stranger to. Thusly, it makes literary sense to expand on the story of Goblin Slayer in the successive episode to capitalize on the horrors a viewer might be feeling when their suspicions of this fantasy world’s nature (i.e the manner in which the citizens of the fantasy world engage with it and how they expect in turn for the world to engage with them. Normal, ordinary people understand that goblins are frightening creatures that do grotesque things and are also aware that there is not much they are capable of. In addition, the state does not care very much about protecting the citizenry from goblins because of how it affects finances), however what occurs instead is that the writer falls onto the trap by treating us to the most bleak version imaginable of this story and in turn the least imaginative and most predictable. Now, some might ask if that even matters – if the purpose of this story is to explore one man’s struggle against this horrific set of circumstances, then there is nothing wrong with this episode. However, what is the purpose of every other aspect of this show that fails to explore this premise? Why should we care about the political affairs of nations or the heroic exploits of characters like the blind priestess woman? If they are not in service to this character study or are not well connected to it, then they are nothing but distractions. Because that is something the grimdark aspect of this show that cares more about being gritty and dark than being contemplative would care more to do. We have hints of a dangerously personal story or one that explores its world through it. Instead, we get neither and one that has more variables at play than it knows what to do with.


Second, is it a narrative about a fantasy world inhabited by terrible abominable creatures? You are telling me that your ideas of executing this premise is by having goblins over and over again commit heinous acts. From the New World is a beloved example of how to have high stakes conflict between two races contain much more complexity. Some might say that is a false equivalency, but we are only comparing one variable here: the role of the “monster” creatures, rats versus goblins. They are both presented as being terrifying. Goblins rape, goblins pillage. Well, rats seem to be capable of reproduction and they certainly also have an aptitude for violence. But there is also more to the rats than that. There is greater complexity between perpetrator (rat) and victim (human) in scenarios where they commit acts comparable to those of goblins in goblin slayer. Why exactly is the degree to which goblins are terrible the same degree to which they serve a purpose in the story? An increase in evil acts by a species does not equate with an increase of quality in their role within the narrative. They are simple tools that the story mashes over a viewer’s head repeatedly without significant progress in their usage amongst the progressing plot. In a manner, it is a narrative about a fantasy world with despicable creatures. It also happens to not have anything more interesting to say other than that.


In that case, we are left with barebones attempt at characterization. After all, it is not so far off in truth that great heroes need to have great villains for their plots. Would Batman be as compelling without his Joker? We see with The Dark Knight Rises how pitiful a narrative can become if even one variable in the equation is not competent enough. Goblins are not compelling creatures narrative-wise or character-wise. There is very little to them besides being the embodiment of evil in this world. The addition that they are mostly male is more flabbergasting than it is intriguing. If Goblin Slayer’s sole motivation is to kill goblins, then you can point the dots about how interesting a character he is capable of becoming.


And do not even utter a word about the little priest girl. All I see is marketing at play.


In terms of art, audio, and animation - we have standard animation. Alright, that is fair. If they are going for a grimdark atmosphere, it would be incorrect to say that the visual aspect does not pay successful service of that because it does. It does the job that is required but it does not go beyond that. It is not criminal. The same would apply to the art; it is not very memorable and uses darker colors for a significant portion of its runtime, which is again not criminal, but it is strikingly another example of where the show is focusing its action. It is “dark”; it is “gritty”. Down to its composition, it demands that the viewer be enthralled in its shadows and to not feel comfortable. But I once more question if the way it is executed has any real value.


On an audio level, there are plenty of examples where hysterical screaming is concerned. They have that sense of panic nailed enough. The opening song is an interesting choice of music, but it is one that is surprisingly welcome. It brings a much needed complexity to the atmosphere. It might be an overtly gritty show, but it has well-crafted flair to open and close its runtime each session. 


All in all, we have a shell. Goblin Slayer is an edifice of artificiality. There is nothing controversial within that statement, but there is not much to walk away with. It is the definition of edgy, an attempt at grimdark with no attributes that make it earned nor is it intentionally innate with a constructed purpose. If we are in it at all, we are in it for a good time but not something worth your time.

Four Episodes in and the series finally starts to feel it is finally finding its footing and pacing. Which is quite understandable with what needed to be phased out of the first two episodes of the series. Some of you may have guessed by now that one of the big things about the manga was it's vivid depicting of the shock factor. Which did not shy away from striking depictions of rape amongst other things? As disturbing as those moments were though, they did help set the pace, tone and narrative that is the Goblin Slayer series. They help elevator the dangers and horrors ofGoblins, establishing not only the fear of a brutal death but the terror of not dying. And set the tone of what makes Goblin Slayer the person, different from adventurers.


By glossing over the first band of adventures (which ruins the fake out that these characters were more involved with the series) and entirely removing the 2nd group of adventures from ep. 2 as well as glossing over how dire and needed goblin slaying is; Goblin Slayer's overall presence comes off a bit diminished than in the manga. We don't get to see the clear difference in his experience not just compared to novices but even a band of experienced adventurers unfamiliar with Goblin tactics. These simple and understandable changes lead to some awkward pacing. Luckily the brutally of Goblin Slayer is enough to hold a fans attention and the series does its best to reintroduce some of the dialogue and ideas back in other ways but a bit of balance is lost when the skip over some of the dialogue and narrative as it originally was.


Episode 3 is a bit awkward too since it also cuts some world and character building as well as crams in more of the manga into an episode then it probably should have, but the pay off comes in Episode 4. Episode 4 comes out untouched by censoring and the dialogue and narrative are allowed to flow at it's intended pace. We finally get into the more methodical nitty, gritty approach of the series then hinted at or glossed over aspects of it from earlier episodes. We get a much better idea and feel of Goblin Slayer's experience and drive. The things that make him different from an Adventurer.


Luckily at this point, the series will go into more and more in what makes Goblin Slayer who he is rather than showing off more shocking moments that need to be censored out and NOW is when I start to get excited about the series. Now that pretty much the porn is out of the way, we can get into the grit of the series. And honestly, now that the series seems to have found itself, it makes the first 3 episodes a bit more understandable and bearable.

Goblin Slayer was a'ight.
I know that's a pretty underwhelming response to such a polarizing series but it encapsulates my feelings towards this show perfectly.
It's merely alright. It's far from great, it's far from awful. It's not a blight upon human society nor do I feel that it's a bastion of grim dark fantasy. Honestly I have more to say about people's reaction to Goblin Slayer than the show itself; but I'll try my best to avoid getting into that and just talk about *the show*.
Goblin Slayer is a dark-fantasy action series about... well... slaying goblins. The actual slaying-of-goblins aspect to the show was admittedly enjoyable.I liked how practical the titular Goblin Slayer was with his goblin-exterminating strategies, and found it to be the show's strong points.


In terms of everything else it's basically your run-of-the-mill fantasy anime, albeit with a protagonist that sticks out from his world like a sore thumb. There's also some occasional moments of grim reality, though they're juxtaposed against busty, moe, anime girls that look like they crawled out of this summer's hottest new Isekai that will be forgotten in a year.


The side cast in Goblin Slayer was also pretty uninteresting and they hit all of your standard D'n'D party tropes. You have the snobby elven archer that's a tsundere, the drunkard dwarf with a loud mouth, the lizard guy that is your stoic hunter-tracker type, and finally the human priestess/healer who is your kawaii "best-girl". They're all relatively inoffensive characters that do little to annoy me nor do they do much to make me give a crap about them. It can be fairly amusing seeing them attempt to converse with our dead-pan Goblin Slayer, but that's about all I got out of them.


In terms of plot, the gang go on a couple goblin-hunting missions and then the show ends. So far no branching story arc has been revealed and it feels almost slice-of-life at times. If you're looking for a satisfying narrative there isn't really one.


With that all out of the way, let's talk about the elephant in the room; the first episode. After finishing the series I can safely say that you can remove the first episode and lose almost nothing besides it setting up how evil the Goblins are. Honestly, showing them murder and pillage the titular character's home village would've been enough to do that, but I digress. I also find it very bizarre how little impact the infamous events of that episode has on the show's secondary character, the Priestess. I'd imagine anyone would be emotionally scarred and incredibly vindictive towards goblins after such an encounter but she seems relatively the same before and after. There's a few brief flash backs to the incident, but she never seems more than mildly perturbed about them.


Which leads me to my main issue with Goblin Slayer; it didn't seem to know what it wanted to be. You could view it as juxtaposition but I see it as tonal confusion. On one hand Goblin Slayer is comedic and pokes fun at fantasy tropes like it's Konosuba, on the other hand it wants to be grim-dark like it's Berserk. In my opinion it manages to hit neither aspect well by trying to be both. The dark moments come off as hilariously out of place and trying too hard, while the comedic moments feel tonally tasteless against the grim events.


All-in-all I think Goblin Slayer is not as bad of a show as it was made out to be by critics, however I don't think it's that good either. The finale gave me some hope that the next season may pick up the pace and find its footing, but for now I wouldn't personally recommend the series.

Released in the fall season of 2018, Goblin slayer, is the animated adaptation of the series of the homonymous light novels written by Kumo Kagyuu and illustrated by Noboru Kannatsuki, which have been published since 2016, and which additional to the anime it also has an adaptation to the manga format also published since 2016. The anime then, released on October 7, 2018, is a production of the White Fox studios, directed by Takaharu Ozaki, which came to have a total of 12 episodes.
Goblin Slayer was an anime that made quite a noise during the premiere of its first episode, not precisely for the bestreasons, to be involved in a controversy, caused by a couple of scenes that occurred during the episode in question, among which you can find a certain scene of rape, which led to more than one being scandalized and scream to heaven, soon cataloging the title as an abomination, and attributing it a lot of nonsense.


Quite a foolish behavior to tell the truth, since not only the scenes in question is not that they were precisely strong (at least in comparison to what this world has been able to offer in the past), but also because many of the criticisms that were made against the anime for this whole situation, did not even take into consideration the context within which these scenes were happening, or the purpose of the series for them, which obviously was to establish the goblins as these horrible creatures and dangerous, as well as make clear the tone for the title, not taking notice also the classification and theme of the work in question.


Now, with all this I mean that Goblin Slayer is some masterpiece of the anime, misunderstood by viewers because of its adult content ?, Not close, but it is definitely not a title nor as sordid or shocking as the chapter in question and so many of what they shouted against or even in favor of it have wanted us to see, being in fact Goblin Slayer a fairly quiet series at times, leaving their "strong" scenes restricted to very specific moments of the title.


Finally, leaving aside all this controversial issue, talk about the series as such, Goblin Slayer is an anime fantasy and adventure, specifically classified as a work of dark fantasy, which takes as a basis a typical world of magic and sword without anything particularly remarkable, inspired as the series itself lets us see more than once, in the classic board game of dungeons and dragons, which tells the adventures of an adventurer known as the Goblin Slayer, which, as the name suggests, is specifically dedicated to ending up with whatever Goblin crosses in the middle, this as a consequence of a traumatic event of his past.


Although in the beginning our protagonist is presented to us as a lonely and somewhat surly adventurer, who does not stand out for his strength or abilities but for his wit, and who only seems to be able to think of goblins, it will not be long before he is around a small and picturesque party to accompany him in his walks, and for those who will eventually begin to feel some appreciation. That said do not expect to find in this series a great adventure story or anything like that, this is not the epic tale of the hero who has to kill the demon king of the day, these are only the stories of an adventurer, although somewhat particular and strange, and how he earns his living doing what he enjoys the most, killing goblins, so at the plot level you do not expect to find anything especially elaborated, being in this sense a very simple title.


The anime then develops under a format typical of these adaptations of light novel, being the same composed of small miniarcs plot between 3 and 4 chapters each, each focused on a mission in which our heroes are involved, which have their appeal both to see how our protagonist manages to eliminate his prey in different ways, bringing with it some moments of good climax, as in what is the interaction between this and his party, resulting in general with this Goblin Slayer a fun and entertaining but at the same time not particularly remarkable or engaging, and I must say that at first the anime is not that it would have called my attention a lot, let's say, finding its first couple of chapters not boring but not with much hook, this largely because both the Goblin Slayer and his first travel companion, the priestess, is not that they are characters especially charismatic, it was not until chapter three with the entry on the scene of the rest of the party, consisting of the elf, the dwarf and the lizardman, that the thing became more entertaining.


Notice that with this I do not mean that the Goblin Slayer and the priestess look like bad characters, correctly fulfilling their role in the series, it's just that they are not enough alone to hold a title that is not particularly striking at first. or catching, being in my opinion what sustains the work most of the time precisely what is the on-screen chemistry of its protagonist quintet.


Visually speaking we are facing a competent but not particularly striking work, and that although the title outlines some attractive character designs, and a well done general animation, of course, except for the use of a CGI not entirely convincing to animate many of the movements of our main character, what was the selection of the color palette did not seem the most successful, occupying the anime a selection of dark and brown tones, which although I understand were chosen to accentuate the dark and dirty environment that adopts the title in some moments, this one is not that it attracts too much nor does it make the series stand out any sense, feeling it on my part something monotonous to see, so that this is not an anime that enters precisely through the eyes.


Finally on the music, there is not much to say, just to mention that the soundtrack really goes unnoticed, plus the title opening "Rightfully" is not bad, finding it personally very attractive, likewise the ending theme, "Gin no Kisei " it also has his thing.


In conclusion, while for the noise that was in the beginning I expected something more, at the end of the day Goblin Slayer is a magic and sword series of traditional ambience quite competent, it is nothing special and for those looking for a story or characters something more elaborated will surely be short, but it is an entertaining job as long as you do not expect much of it.

Honestly, Goblin Slayer was not an anime that I planned on watching. For a while, I just thought it would be a boring fantasy anime. 
But, clearly, I was wrong. Goblin Slayer is a slightly darker fantasy anime with action and you should at least feel entertained while watching. As the name suggests, the anime is about slaying goblins. Along with that though is watching the main character's progress. And that goes for a lot of things such as his social circle, his personality, and the way he expresses his emotions. Overall, the story is a bit repetitive. I admit that. It's basically just themfighting goblins over and over again. Each fight is a little different though because of the use of strategies and the turn of events. (Also, just so you know, you don't have to worry about anything too graphic. That certain scene everyone was talking about isn't all that bad. Trust me. It's for the sake of setting the show's atmosphere.)


The art's not all that unique looking. It's pretty much like your average anime with a few exceptions. I like the character designs and backgrounds though. The CGI wasn't too bad. It was noticeable but not an eyesore. The overall animation was pretty good too.


The opening and ending songs are great. I feel like there was some wasted potential with the opening animation but it's ok the way it is. And the OSTs are never oddly timed. They always make the fight scenes better when they're used. 


The characters didn't really gain any noticeable development. They were basically the same from start to finish. The only thing that could be easily pointed out is the main character's development and his relationships with others. This isn't necessarily a bad thing though if you don't care about development.

Right from the very start Goblin Slayer had an infamous reputation, due to a pretty disturbing to some opening episode. The general disgust towards *that* scene was really overblown. And the scene was really short. If anything, I appreciate it, because it shows right from the start that the show can be rather dark and that this fantasy world is not all lighthearted, as there are plenty such shows.
Goblin Slayer is a series about, as the title says, goblin slaying. There isn't, in terms of story, much more to it. It might not sound overly exciting, but it is pretty interesting and, in my opinion,worth watching. At the end of the day it all depends on your preferences though.


If you think about it, the story is rather bland. Goblin Slayer takes quests to slay goblins, at first alone, later on with a party. There is no connection between the quests except for character introductions really. The show barely focuses on worldbuilding. There are many references to D&D, like 'gods rolling a dice' or something. It is made pretty clear, especially at the very last episode, what this series is based on. 

There are 'filler' episodes, in a sense that the party is refilling equipment, repairing gear or just chilling/partying. What I find most interesting is that the MC-kun is very clearly specified to not be a special individual in the world, as there are heroes who literally save the world when he's on a goblins quest. The season doesn't end on a cliffhanger, rather the opposite - I'd say it ends in a satisfying way. Although more is always welcome, I'd be fine if it ended here, because there aren't really any unanswered questions or unaddressed plot points that come to mind.


Speaking of animation, there is CGI but not that much and it's not terrible. 2D animation however is pretty good. It's not the most detailed or anything but it certainly shouldn't bug your mind. There is a lot of blood. Very gory scenes are censored fairly well. Overall, the animation certainly fits with the theme of the show. It doesn't have the highest budget ever but is consistently good.


When the show wants to be 'badass', it is. With the help of really fitting soundtracks. Again, not masterpieces or something stellar, they get the job done and get you excited and hyped for the action scene. Voice actors portrayed their characters really well.

Speaking of soundtracks, both opening and ending songs are really good. I often find myself listening to them.


I've seen many comparisons between Goblin Slayer (we don't even know his name) and Guts. In my opinion, it is stupid. GS and Berserk are two entirely different series and the characters don't have much in common, except for endurance and *maybe* personality (again, only because Guts isn't the most talkative person in the world). Speaking of GS, he doesn't have much of said personality. He usually replies with just 'I see.' or 'Okay.' or 'Really?' when it comes to daily conversations. He may sound like a boring character, which he might be, but his bland personality is sometimes pretty hilarious. He starts off as a loner, however as the story goes on, we see him learn the importance of nakama, friends, etc. He starts caring about his party even if he doesn't outright say so. Also, the last arc was basically dedicated to save his childhood friend. In battle however, he is the one who comes up with a plan and provides much knowledge on goblins.

We also given hints on what made GS the way he is - obsessed with goblin slaying, not talkative, etc but there also is a spin-off manga focusing on his backstory.


Goblin Slayer, a few episodes in, forms a party of four. While they are not developed much as well, they bring an interesting dynamic to the group and I found myself actually caring for them, their interactions with each other are always fun. In battle they bring interesting strategies and abilities. Characters didn't really grow very much in terms of writing, but they didn't need to, in my opinion. It's not a show you watch if you want to witness complex characters anyway and it wouldn't really fit into the general theme and story.


When the show is serious, it is pretty badass. There was never a time when I felt like skipping an episode or even a scene. Where it fails in character depth/worldbuilding/telling an incredible story, it makes up with hype moments and really enjoyable battles, interactions between characters.

Story 5/10
This story is nothing special. It is stated in the name of the anime itself, a Goblin, Slayer. It's about a guy that slays goblins. Whether the slaying be in one episode or a full three there is enough slaying of goblins for the entire family to enjoy! This show begins of just like your normal isekai anime, but it turns for the worse when the idea of rape and naked girls is brought into thepicture. Now this is where many people have a problem with the show, but I don't see it. You have shows like Berserk that show just the same kind of things, if not worse, but you see that show getting praise while Goblin Slayer is all hate. I personally haven't seen Berserk the anime but I have read several chapters in the manga, but I digress. You have small 'arcs' if you would like to call them in Goblin Slayer, which is basically just a quest. The longest one is the quest they take to slay Goblins under a city, offered by a High Priestess. This High Priestess is apparently important, but we only see her for, like, two episodes so I don't get it. Of course every show of this kind has to have it's epic battle to end the show and I'm going to be honest, I quite liked it. It lasted for the last two episodes and I liked to see all of the characters come back for one final battle with everyone. Summary: In the end, one could pick up an episode at the beginning of a quest, watch the single quest alone, and get satisfaction. For me specifically, this story was not the most memorable thing in the world. For these reasons, it is a 5/10.


Art 8/10

This won't be as long as the Story paragraph, and I'll try to keep it short. This art style has elements of your normal isekai, but not as stand out-ish as other isekai like konosuba. This is most likely because of the darker tone of Goblin Slayer, but the mix of vibrant colors along with darker, less saturated colors mixes for a great world. I feel the CGI for Goblin Slayer's armor is one of the better instances of CGI in anime. Certainly not the best, but definitely not the worst. Summary: A nice combination of colors, along with the character design and CGI, give Art an 8/10.


Sound 7/10

The Opening and Ending were something to skip over. While the OP is definitely better than the ED, I found that I skipped over the Opening 9/12 episodes (1,11,12 are the three I didn't skip) and skipped over the ending 12/12 episodes. What really earns the high rating is the Sound Effects and VA. I really don't have any complaints for any of the Voice Actors, however some were just alright. The Sound Effects, such as the goblins and the death of them, are very good and sometimes I even jumped a little when after a quite moment a goblin sound would play. Summary: Because the OP and ED were easily skippable, but the sound effects and Voice Actors were very good, Sound ends at a 7/10.


Character 6/10 (I purposely botch the names)

This is kind of a mixed bag for me. On one hand you have very in depth characters, and on the other you have "likes person because anime". Of course you have the classic characters such as Mr. Dense Protagonist, Holy Girl who might like Goblin Slayer-san but is never said because PLOT, Ms. Elf Lady who says no fire water or poison, Mr. Drunk Dwarf (who also gets into fights with Elf Lady), and Cheese Loving McGee.These 5 are who you follow through the majority of the show, not really learning about who they are, where they come from, their backstory (except for Mr. Dense Boy), or in some cases how they met. Where does Cheese Loving McGee come from and why does he love Cheese? How did Elf Lady and Drunk Dwarf end up in the same party? These questions and many more are never solved in the series, even though the directors could've taken maybe 1 or 2 episodes to go in depth about them towards the beginning of the show. Even Ms. Farm Tit has more character development than Elf Lady, who has more screen time in one episode than she has in her entirety. Side characters seem to have also been included simply for the reason of being 'comedic effect' or rivalry for some girl. Summary: While maybe 1 or 2 characters are gone into development, the rest are not. However, because they are memorable characters, Character gets a 6/10.


Enjoyment 7/10

For as much as I've been writing the negatives of the show, I did happen to enjoy it quite a bit. Enjoyment is the only relative part of a review so I will sum it up in the following statement. Summary: Because of memorable characters, great art and sound design, characters who keep me wondering who they are, amongst other reasons, my Enjoyment is a 7/10.

Goblin Slayer, the anime that everyone either loves the hell out of it or just plain hates it. I didn't after the fiasco that Darling in the Franxx caused in 2018, there was any anime would come out this year that would have everyone in the community talk about it. Well Goblin Slayer has manages to done that. Now is it the best thing to come out of the fantasy/MMORPG genre or plain worst anime in the history. If anyone asked me, i would describe the Goblin Slayer anime after five episodes in one word: AVERAGE. Yes, it's just an average showwhich just has a bit more edge over most shows of the same genre. Now let's break down the Goblin Slayer anime.


Story: 6/10


There is an old saying that you can not judge a book by its cover. Well Goblin Slayer disagrees with that. It is what is on the tin. An anime about slaying Goblins. In this anime Goblins are not your absolute weak tier10 monsters. They are evil and a bit smart( not to mention too horny) and the anime is about dealing with them. While simple stories can be great with good execution, Goblin Slayer till now has handled it averagely not making the story stand out. Five episodes in, the world building hasnt been upto the mark or the execution hasnt been spot on. However this could have been worse.


Art: 8/10


This is the strongest point of the Goblin Slayer anime. While the art isn't something revolutionary, it is on point. The color contrasts are on point with the tones of the show and animation never seems half-hearted. Considering the year 2018, the art of the show is upto the mark. White Fox haven't half-assed the project just because this was something untested.


Sound: 7/10


Not much to say about the sound of the show. Okay OST, decent OP, not so decent ED. Considering it was produced by White Fox, I expected a bit more on the sound department as well.


Character: 5/10


This is where the show has a huge flaw. If you are making a good anime, you should be invested in the characters by episode 4-5. But five episodes in, there is nothing that would make you root for or feel a connection with any of the characters. Before you go and say read the manga/LN or wait a bit, Good anime always make sure you have some investment in the show important characters. All the characters in the show are one note. Character interactions seem forced. The characters are making the show suffer.


Enjoyment: 5/10


Despite of heavily criticizing Goblin Slayer, i would say this. I did enjoy it quite a bit. It isn't something extraordinary. But if you have free time, you can give the show a go.


Overall: 7/10


Now before giving an overall rating and review of the show lets discuss a few things first. First comes the infamous rape scene. Is it the worst thing to happen in anime? Well, no. There have been far worse execution of rape scenes in anime I can think of(every other edgelord anime). Goblin Slayer, however is not one to be up there among those. Hell, even Berserk despite of being so good, didnt do an excellent job at that. So just dissing the anime on basis of the rape scene only isn't right. Goblin Slayer used simple shock factor to draw in an audience successfully. But is it really that good? The answer here will also be no. Shows like Re:Zero and Made in Abyss have shown you dont need to rely solely on shock factor to establish a brutal fantasy world. Sadly, without its shock factor, Goblin Slayer cannot establish its brutality. Overall, it is just an average show that only a teenager would think that its the best or worst thing to happen in anime.

What is the path of gaining popularity in matter of no time? By doing something extreme, of course. Goblin Slayer nailed with the first episode by exceeding in unnecessary amount of violence and gore, which disgusted some people not because tons of gore is a nasty thing, but because many parts had terrible action (usually two characters are fighting while others are waiting for their turn, or someone goes banzai and dies in an instant), awfully made protagonist and antagonists.
The story is cliche as it can be, generic fantasy world with names like kingdom of elves, they didn't even bother naming kingdoms (not mentioning nonexistentnames of the characters), already seen and used races like dwarves, humans, elves, argonians... umm I mean lizards, etc. Races want to survive and of course evil creatures such as goblins and demons want to ruin everything, so they fight. There is adventurer's guild with a plenty of quests which offer rewards, though it looks like typical high school show - boasting jocks, an elite group which despises others, which wasn't necessary at all... 

The characters don't have names. We know someone's race and age, bit of protagonist's past, and that's mostly it. The conversations are usually dull, it's either talk about how bad goblins are, pathetic  bantering between the elf and the dwarf, or when the protagonist replies with one or two words to everything. The other problem with characters is such awful design (especially the voice) of goblins, not just that they look like someone with no imagination created them, they don't leave any impression of posing a threat with their pathetic figure and voice. Swiper from Dora the Explorer looks scarier than the goblins. Also, the logic about protagonist and his armour is ridiculous, but I guess he needs to look like a tough guy who doesn't talk much to leave cool impression. Never taking his armour off, even helmet, while helmets were worn only during the battle or duty as a guard, eating (not even removing his visor) and sleeping in armour and helmet looks more silly than cool and tough. 


With all these flaws, it's not a terrible show. The first episode was a teaser that the show will be dark and full of gore and other nasty things, but it hasn't shown any more depth than that. Characters with no names, kingdoms with no names, even the dark theme started fading away with the annoying elf and the atmosphere is changing. Dark theme is getting thinner and the show is shifting into a forgettable seasonal anime with some adventure time and action, nothing more.


I guess there will be some demon master who summons evil creatures to take over the world and eliminate all the races or turn them into slaves, the protagonist will probably have another scroll to use as a trump card and poof, the end.

"A BARRACK OF SWORDS AND SORCERY HOLDING JAPANESE SWAMP UNDER THE FLOOR"
On a story posting site, there submitted an amateurish simple draft like a rough dry trail. To tailor it into a suite of animation series, it is necessary to flesh out with ideas which were not given by the original plotter. What this production team chose was...
In the characteristics of Japanese ghost stories and Japanese horror movies, there is an element, which is always pointed out. To say, "dampness".
In the dictionary sense, it appears to be "water". Half of it is from the climate and a depressing mood (such as quiet eeriness) made bythat. The other half is body fluid of human. Cold sweat on the back, dry swallow in tense, striking nausea in the stomach, the sudden eruption of hot flashes, feeling slippy hands holding the shaft of a weapon, sticky blood pool, tears overflowing while holding back the cry, and so on. Actors and viewers share the same kind of body fluids as humanity. They are shaken by the emotions mediated by the body fluids. The emotions that cannot be spoken are again symbolized and emphasized as the body fluids.


A strong thought that every human being has, shaped into a certain direction by own emotions are called "pathos". In the type of stories like this work, "pathos" can be said more concisely -- "grudge".


The terse drafts, like the inscrutable iron-faced protagonist. In order to make a foothold of empathy and inflate the plot, highlighting more sympathetic characters to stir viewers' primal emotions is a proper way.

Not a disastrous mass destruction nor terror, but the concerns of this story are the lawless violence (sometimes organized and sometimes disorganized) also seen in this real world. What the creative team chose is simmering the grudges of the characters and the goblins, with tenacity. The dampness is its physical representation.


Some of the audience (some are chuunibyo) assume that this "low sugar" mood takes on the western-medieval style hard-core fantasy with harsh realism, which landed as a counteraction of those fluffy lots of Japan-born swords-and-sorcery contents which are bright, refreshing and stress-free for an empty head (but filled with eye candies).

The direct ancestor of anti-hero archetype like the protagonist of this work can be sought out on the tracks back to the Spaghetti Western movies. As you know very well, there was a period when many movies set in the West of America were produced in European countries. Contrary to the conventional stories of the high-spirited proud founders of America who have devoted their lives to the pioneering and faith, the Spaghetti Western movies portray who openly oppose the corrupted authorities, who resist racial discrimination, the Mexican heroes who lead American armies by the nose, nihilistic stylish outlaws and so on. The movies oriented to the action entertainment in the desolated frontiers.

Some of what the Spaghetti producers have been inspired were Akira Kurosawa's "Yojinbo" and those "jidai-geki" -- historical sword-action drama / samurai movies. On the contrary, the Spaghetti Western echoes to the Japanese drama makers. Pushing those repetitious "moral play" aside, stranger heroes appeared after another who live on their rules and sole own swordsmanship.

It seems that the original draft of this work also took nutrients from a pool of jidai-geki, like the game masters of paper-and-pencil role-playing games prepare scenarios conceived from plots of those established plays. And the animated version is borrowing a lot from Japanese traditional standard attributes: "damp" and "wet", as mentioned.

Even though this is not such another tale like brave adventures of teen boys and/or girls with a critter (which are commercially proven by the video game industry as so-called "JRPG"s), it is also and nevertheless a work, which is undoubtedly fed by the bloodline of accustomed Japanese storytelling doctrine.


Aside from the ethical controversy, such these stories like revenge, horror or bullying which are driven by gruesome "grudges" are promised certain approval and success, especially in East Asia. However, the way is to immerse its knees into the warm swamp from the prehistoric era where countless previous works and tales stagnant. I still can not tell whether it breaks to a new route without getting bogged down, whether it can continue to breathe even after mired in the mushy ooze, nor whether it will be pulled into fathoms deep and buried totally.

It took me a bit to get Goblin Slayer's actual appeal points and it's greatest strengths, but thanks to that I think I've gained an even bigger appreciation for this series. The original manga is supposedly very gory and disturbing, but the anime tones that aspect down a bit - the fights are still bloody and brutal, but torture and rape (which are important to the whole setup, as they explain the nasty nature of goblins and the danger they represent) are shown explicitly only in the opening episode. The rest of the content is simply a fantasy adventure, with the protagonist facing more andmore grim challenges and reluctantly teaming up with other heroes to overcome them.


The "tabletop-session" climate is augmented by the "gamey" rules of the world (like the limited number of spells characters can use per day) and very peculiar character development - pretty much everyone in the story is addressed in accordance to their function, rather than names and there's only a necessary minimum of world-building or plot progression. The only thing that really matters is the main group and the specific challenges they face, which leads to some fun interactions and highly satisfying fights.


Another unusual part is the protagonist, whose single-minded obsession with eradicating goblins and disinterest in the rest of the world is something I haven't really seen in a lead character. He basically only talks, walks and breaths to kill them, making for many absurd situations and dialogue (and, what's important to mention, he's really an expert at his job - a professional exterminator of sorts, but one that doesn't care about being paid or thanked for what he does). His companions have a bit more personality, but are also kept close to their respective archetypes (and that's visibly on purpose).


Everything mentioned so far is, obviously, done with some really impressive production values. There were also some parts of the show I liked less, such as the awkward fanservice and over-stylized support characters, but generally, it was an enjoyable experience - and it should be the same for you, if you can get into the right mood and accept its peculiar formula.

I enjoyed Goblin Slayer honestly way more than I ever should have. I wish I could say it's a deep show or even one that's particularly special in some artistic way, but it's not. Goblin Slayer is a show with exactly one sole purpose, and that is killing goblins. In some odd way however, that singular goal alone is what makes this show enjoyable. It isn't some story about a hero saving the world, it isn't a story about some chosen one. It's a simple, mostly focused story about a man who is so deeply disturbed he does the onlything he knows how to. 


   While this show isn't perfect in any means, I found the inspiration taken from D&D to be quite fun. Just like the world of D&D, Goblin Slayer is a rough world in which terrible act occur. Personally, a darker tone is not an issue for me in a show, however I do feel like it could have been handled better. While Goblin Slayer puts fourth interesting and dark ideas, it doesn't capitalize on them as much as say something like Berserk would. 


   I can't go any longer without talking about one of the most hotly dated issues with the show though, and that is the depiction of rape in it. Now I think depicting such a topic in a show can be done right, and for the most part it is. However the one thing that turned me off of Goblin Slayer was the tone in regards to sexualization. Now the scenes themselves are not sexualized, however, there is quite an ungodly amount of fan service in this show. I'm not prude, but considering the tone this show wishes to have, it feels incredibly out of place and really took me out of it at multiple moments.


    Overall though if you are a fan of D&D and other such roleplaying games, I would recommend at least giving it a try. If you can manage to look past some of the flaws of the show, it's a relatively enjoyable experience that has good ideas. I wouldn't say it's fantastic by any means, but I can say I got some enjoyment out of it during my time watching.

I have been delaying reviewing my fall shows for a while but decided to sit down and finally write them. 
Anyhow Goblin Slayer is a show that is heavily influenced by tabletop D&D. This influence can be seen during an episode where a magic caster explains they only can use a certain number of spells per day.  It is a different approach to the typical fantasy anime. 
 Unfortunately, we do have to talk about what happened in the first episode and the rape stuff. To my memory, nothing is shown explicitly but it is a pretty graphic scene, and I get why therebe a debate about it. It would be something if the animation studio were trying to make a point about it or open a broader conversation, but after the first episode nothing like that shows up again.  There is a definite sense the showrunners were trying to capitalize on the shock value to get a couple more viewers or be in the spotlight.


There is nothing that stands out too much about the characters other than the titular Goblin Slayer.  Goblin Slayer has developed an obsession for killing goblins after the horrific rape and murder of his sister by them in an attack on his village in his youth.  Ironically, this brings up a fascinating discussion about the nature of threat. Wisecrack has a video that does a much better job explaining it than I ever could so check it out if interested. No one had proper names, just denotations of what they do, again harkening to the theme of tabletop.


The battle scenes are done well. It was always fun to see how Goblin Slayer went about his craft of slaying goblins or how he will thwart their machinations to kill him. 

Soundwise, the only thing memorable to me, was the OP. I watched the Dub it did a good job nothing that would make me want to switch.


The problem is Goblin Slayer at the end of the day is rather a bland show nothing amazing but nothing terrible an okay show.

Goblin slayer. It had a really strong opening, full of gore and other kind of brutal stuff. Honestly, it was really epic because of how brutal it was. Props for that, it really hooked me up there. The problem is, is that it didn't properly reflect the overall mood of the anime, which resulted in me being really disappointed and bored. The only reason why I'd maybe continue it, is my hope for another intense moment like the first episode, but that hope wasn't strong enough this time so I'm dropping it.

In most fantasy, heroes kill monsters because, well, they're MONSTERS! They exist to be killed by heroes, don't they?!
Not so in Goblin Slayer... Here the little green devils are shown to be a cruel and despicable menace that clearly must be dealt with by the sword. This gives the show a bit more emotional weight, at least at first.
But as much as I was prepared to love this anime, I just can't muster much enthusiasm for it in the end, because the characters are so lacking. The Goblin Slayer himself is a man of few words, and even worse, it's always the same few words!Hearing him say the same short catch phrases in response to anything that happens around him gets old real quick. This makes him incredibly lackluster and unrelatable as a main character, especially since he never removes his stupid helmet!


The rest of the cast is mediocre and/or cut from the most worn fantasy tropes. None of them have much to offer in terms of personality, and it's hard to really care about any of them.


There are other things that went wrong with this show too, such as the fact goblins are causing a lot of suffering and death, but only the Goblin Slayer seems to care about it. This kind of inconsistency shows a broken world-building. To be honest, I think the world of GS is just a grab bag of standard fantasy tropes borrowed from everywhere, with little to no care taken to make sure it at least fits together.


But that doesn't really matter! I can easily forgive world inconsistencies and plot contrivances and even poorly structured writing, as long as the story is interesting and the characters relatable. Neither is the case here.


It's just not a very good show, but I still award it a 5, because at no point was I tempted to drop it. It has a lot of action, and it's mildly interesting to see what happens next. There's even a few semi-memorable moments sprinkled throughout the season. I'm not sure it's enough to recommend it, but it's at least enough to not warn people away. Go for it if you're in the mood for some forgettable low brow action entertainment.


But stay away if watching goblins get whacked triggers you! There's a lot of goblin gore on offer here. I usually stay away from gore and excessive violence, but here it's just goblins having their skulls cleaved, so I don't really care...

I initally avoided Goblin Slayer due to all the controversy. I thought it was some overhyped, edgy trash like everyone seemed to be making it out to be. I should have known better, that it could not be farther from the truth. 
Goblin Slayer is the breath of fresh, unadulterated, vile air in this cloistering age of hypersensitivity and social coddling. Apparently murder, violence, and death are A okay to be shown in all forms of media, and no one bats an eye. But sexual assault and rape is a taboo of the highest severity, the damn Voldemort of evil. It shall not be acknowledged,can never be spoken of or shown, because it might offend someone. Showing murder, dismemberment, and gratuitous violence is totally fine; nobody has any personal tragedies that might be evoked by its imagery. But showing rape will set the Internet on fire. Give me a break.


I believe Shadiversity said something that perfectly sums up the show: "Goblin Slayer makes monsters monstrous again." I think it's fantastic that Goblin Slayer didn't hold back with its scenes of gore, and graphic violence and rape. I'm glad it makes the viewer uncomfortable, asking in disbelief "Did that really just happen?" Yes it did. These are GOBLINS, not some neutered PC ripoff of them. These are vile, despicable, hedonistic, evil creatures. That's what makes them compelling and gives them depth. That's why you cheer wholeheartedly as Goblin Slayer proves his namesake, even in the most unsavory of situations. Especially in the most unsavory situations.


Alright enough about that controversy. Let me address some other points briefly.


Story

Author does a fantastic job with subverting traditional tropes associated with the adventure genre. In this world with dragons and demons and a mutlitude of other eldritch horrors... Goblin Slayer slays goblins. He's a very predictable fellow, but his ingenuity and expertise in approaching goblin slaying really makes each conflict engaging and draws you further into the story.


Art

Pretty standard-good art. As you probably know, Goblin Slayer himself is drawn with CGI, which can be a bit abrasive in contrast with the rest of the cast. Still does a much better job of utilizing CGI than say Overlord or Berzerk.


Sound

Phenomenal sound design. This show really proved to me something I had always taken to be true but never really appreciated: that sound design can make or break the show. Numerous times throughout the series I got goosebumps just from the anticipation I felt when I heard the battle music kick in or the anxiety/dread from the 'brace for tragedy' tracks.

Above all I really can't express how beautiful the OP is. If nothing else, watch the Goblin Slayer OP. As soon as I saw it, I immediately knew it was in the top 5 best OPs of all time. It's so simple, yet elegant and powerful at the same time. Above all, Rightfully, the song in the OP just checks all my boxes, and hearing it instantaneously alters my mood. you'll just have to listen to it yourself.


Characters

Most of the cast is pretty archetypical. The way in which Goblin Slayer interacts slightly differently with each, and the possibilities they provide for growth and bonding really adds a new dimension of interest to the show. One of the most commonly cited and my favorite relationship is that between Goblin Slayer and High Elf Archer. Their personalities and motivations for becoming adventurers are near opposites. As they spend more time together and they come to understand each other more deeply, they subtly start to swap traits and mannerisms. This is exceedingly apparent by Goblin Slayer's proclamation in the last episode, which I'll leave you to connect once you finish watching.

I also want to mention how much I love the character of Goblin Slayer himself. He really feels like a broken, apathetic man, yet you can sense his good-natured and kind core beneath. Other MCs generally always act the simlarly; they are animated, conscientious, reciprocate feelings, try to impress others, show great depth of emotions (flustered, confident, inspired, depressed). Goblin Slayer just has one mode, one range of emotions: Gobling Slaying. It's refreshing to see how easily and unintentionally he deflates every situation, and how he begins to change under the influence of Priestess and High elf Archer.


Overall/Enjoyment

I don't think this show is quite a 10, but for it's undeserved controversy, ingenious soundtrack, numerous refreshing elements, and DnD theme, I'll give it the benefit of the doubt.


Watch it. And if you aren't sold, at least watch the brilliant OP.

This anime is a masterclass in minimalistic storytelling.  The plot is as simple as it can possibly be: "A man slays goblins.".  That's LITERALLY it.  There are no plot twists, no complex and multi-layered tales, nothing thought provoking at all.  Just a man who was traumatized as a child who grew up obsessed with killing the goblins who destroyed his village.  And it's not even told in a kind of "revenge tale" way.  There's no "end point" or main enemy to kill that will satisfy the Goblin Slayer.  He will do this forever because of his trauma andthere's nothing glorious or grandiose about it.  If anything, Goblin Slayer is looked at as nothing more than a pest exterminator.  No one respects his obsession with goblins and the anime doesn't even try to make it fanciful, like he'll ultimately become an elite superhero.  He's just a guy who kills goblins and openly rejects any greater ambitions than that.  


And even though that's all this anime is, it turns out to be fantastic.  It's creative in its own way, forging a completely unique perspective on the fantasy genre.  Instead of doing the usual crescendo of "nobody adventurer who rises up to fight the demon lord and save the world", it chooses to focus on the dirty, grunt work of low level adventuring in a gritty and brutal way. (And yes, this anime is gory and brutal, and includes lots of rape and victimization of women.)  


That's probably the most interesting thing about this anime, is how goblins are portrayed.  Normally, goblins are just throwaway monsters that MC's don't deal with after the first couple of episodes.  A 60 second fight, before they go on to face dragons or fallen demons or something.  This anime focuses on the reality of what a goblin would actually be like in real life.  It's a monster, too.  It kills, it kidnaps, it rapes, it's evil all on its own and in a horde, they can destroy whole towns.  Goblins actually would be terrifying in real life and this anime really depicted that.  It's a stark contrast in comparison to how the goblins of animes like TenSura are depicted.      


Beyond this, the fights with the goblins themselves were often very well done.  The Goblin Slayer got no respect from his peers, and yet, he was extremely skilled after years of fighting with goblins.  The battles reflected that as he used various strategies to defeat them.  But, he didn't just run over them in every fight.  He put his life on the line, as did his comrades.  You never feel like it's a guarantee they'll come out of the battle alive.  That made for very tense battles that added to the anime's suspense.  


In such a simple anime, that focused on the realism of what a goblin threat would actually look like in a fantasy world, there wasn't much emphasis on the cast or character development.  That would probably be the weak point of Goblin Slayer, but it doesn't really detract too much from the anime, because you realize when watching it, it's just a story about a man who fights goblins.  So, the MC was very stoic, and his crew tended to be one dimensional.  You've seen the fantasy tropes: The boisterous dwarf and the haughty elf who can't get along.  The healer priestess who worries about the health of the MC.  Nothing different here, other than the cheese loving lizardman.  But, that was pretty much the extent of his character: He loved cheese.  Everything was very simple.  But, it all just worked to create an entertaining anime.  


Having watched so many fantasy animes, this was a refreshing take on the genre that doesn't make you think too much or try to do too much.  It's something you just sit back and enjoy.  It was very good to be so simple and it succeeded in one of the hardest things for animes to do these days: It finished well.  The last episodes of the anime are the best episodes of the anime.  That's seems to be a rare feat these days.
